						 Competencies Framework for Civil Dialogue around Race Relations 
					 

					 
						 Background\xc2\xa0 
 The Rapid Response Team (RRT) on Civil Discourse was given as part of charge from the Extension Committee on Operations and Policy (ECOP) to identify or assemble set of competencies that help promote civil dialogue on race relations.\xc2\xa0 The RRT gratefully acknowledges contributions of Extension specialists and others with proficiency on this topic for their contributions in assembling and vetting the competency framework that follows. 
 Civil dialogue involves creating safe place for community members to assemble to discuss challenging question.\xc2\xa0 The process of dialogue typically involves some level of facilitation, agreement to set of guidelines, and has central focus on increasing understanding among participants on the topic.\xc2\xa0 The process may or may not lead to consensus or action.\xc2\xa0 Yet civil dialogue will always seek to foster listening and understanding. 
 This particular framework focuses the dialogue efforts on race relations given the intense discord that has been evident over the past year.\xc2\xa0 Many of the competencies identified throughout this document, though, have much broader application to other issues that cause divide in society including other challenges around diversity, inclusion, and equity, as well as other types of challenges that occur in communities. 
 \xc2\xa0 
 Introduction 
 Becoming competent in facilitating civil dialogue around race relations requires broad skill set.\xc2\xa0 Within that set are two partially overlapping subsets of skills from which the professional must draw to be effective.\xc2\xa0 One set of skills relates directly to the ability to organize, convene, and lead an effort to bring people together around any challenging issue.\xc2\xa0 The other skill set is directly related to competencies around multi-cultural communication and interaction.\xc2\xa0 While person could be competent within one of these spheres and not the other, to effectively facilitate civil dialogue around the unique challenges of race relations involves the intersection of both sets of skills.\xc2\xa0 Mastery of the combined competencies will equip the professional to analyze situation, determine an appropriate approach, engage others in organizing for longer term program or event, prepare for the process, foster participation, and facilitate resulting action.\xc2\xa0 Through the lens of race relations, the professional will also be keenly aware of how culture and context may impact given situation, and will carefully lead the process in such way as to promote understanding and healing. 
 Two Spheres of Civil ialogue around Race Relations 
 
 The Rapid Response Team recognizes that building competencies around civil dialogue to address race relations is but one aspect of preparing Cooperative Extension Service professionals to support communities.\xc2\xa0 Our country is grappling with how to engage in civil dialogue across range of social and policy issues such as employment, housing, immigration, religion, sexual orientation, political values, poverty, and others.\xc2\xa0 Race and issues of structural racism can often be the underbelly beneath many of these issues.\xc2\xa0 While this document focuses primarily on competencies to engage on the issue of race relations, we recognize that many competencies are transferable, but additional expertise may be warranted to prepare the professional to address wider range of issues.\xc2\xa0 Thus, given the original charge to the team, this document focuses primarily on issues around race relations. 
 
 I. \xc2\xa0Civil Dialogue Overview 
 Before dialogue process can effectively take shape, community organizers/facilitators need some basic understanding of what dialogue is and when and how it can successfully move community forward in addressing challenging issue or at least better understanding it. 
 
 Understand the importance of dialogue in addressing challenging issues. 
 Recognize multiple ways of knowing that influence the way people think about issues. 
 Understand and can explain the realms impacting community decision-making (diagram). 
 Identify factors influencing the type of public input that may be appropriate in given situation. 
 Recognize situations in which dialogue may be appropriate and when it may not. 
 
 
 II. \xc2\xa0Civil Dialogue and the Land Grant University (LGU) 
 Aligning civil dialogue efforts with the Land Grant mission sometimes leads to puzzling questions. In order to successfully integrate civil dialogue into the LGU work, an understanding of how the two fit together\xe2\x80\x94or are challenged to do so\xe2\x80\x94will help pave the way to successful university-community collaboration (see Wright, 2012). 
 
 Understand the history of Extension as grassroots knowledge-sharing and relationship-building institution, particularly the role that group discussion and civil dialogue has played in its history (Shaffer, 2016). 
 Recognize how dialogue can strengthen Extension work with communities (Hustedde, 1996) 
 Articulate the value of civil dialogue to both the LGU as well as to communities 
 Balance \xe2\x80\x9cdeliver science based knowledge\xe2\x80\x9d with community engagement to work alongside communities for solutions (Peters, 2014). 
 Recognize community building as one of everyone in Extension\xe2\x80\x99s tasks. 
 Address common misperceptions of Extension\xe2\x80\x99s involvement in civil dialogue such as Extension\xe2\x80\x99s mission and potential roles in conflict. 
 Understand Extension\xe2\x80\x99s own unique challenges in reaching all audiences within given community. 
 
 
 III. \xc2\xa0Background Analysis 
 Before engaging the community in civil dialogue, good understanding of the situation is needed.\xc2\xa0 This foundation should identify major stakeholders/viewpoints, provide baseline data related to the scope of the issue, and articulate the issue clearly to those that might be interested in engaging in conversation. 
 
 Understand and acknowledge how issues become controversial 
 Identify key elements of the situation including why the issue is contentious, scale and trends locally, historical background, stakeholders, power-brokers, and assets/resources available. 
 Know where to find and how to analyze relevant data 
 Determine if dialogue project should be undertaken based on analysis 
 Frame an issue in neutral, inclusive, non-threatening manner in order to promote productive, civil deliberative discussion. 
 Quickly adapt the analysis and associated framing as new information is identified or as the situation changes. 
 
 
 IV. \xc2\xa0Community Organizing 
 Once determination is made to hold dialogue session, organizing the community to ensure diverse, broad-base of participants relative to the situation is essential to success. 
 
 Understand the elements of creating safe space for dialogue relative to organization (geographic location, timing, selecting moderators and facilitators, etc.) 
 Identify, recruit, and lead planning team that is representative of the voices within the issue and of the community itself and including those already active on the issue and also youth. Fully engage them in the planning process. 
 Garner needed resources for successful dialogue. 
 Understand the different approaches to engagement and dialogue and properly identify the best approach for the situation. 
 Craft community invitations that clearly articulate the purpose and that reach all relevant stakeholder groups effectively, using multiple sources and mediums that are appropriate to the situation. Invite involvement rather than mandating participation. 
 Identify and train volunteers for facilitating civil dialogue. 
 Understand the various leadership roles that may be present in dialogue planning and implementation process (facilitator/coordinator/coach/teacher/co-creator/convener/trainer); determine the appropriate role for yourself in the situation, weighing both professional and personal aspects. 
 
 
 V. \xc2\xa0Processes and Skills in Dialogue 
 Effectively facilitating dialogue process involves watchful attention to how people are interacting together throughout the effort.\xc2\xa0 Attention to key areas are vital to success. 
 
 Design process appropriate to the situation and available time. State as clearly as possible the approach, timeframe, and goals of the dialogue process. 
 Manage the facilitator role appropriately (neutral, interjecting questions or comments appropriately). 
 Foster safe and inviting environment for dialogue. 
 Assist the group in developing shared vision. 
 Support the group in setting norms or group agreements 
 Maintain positive conversation flow, shepherding dialogue progression through appropriate questions, reflective silence, and natural dialogue among participants. 
 Foster respectful, balanced, and authentic discussion among all dialogue participants. 
 Understand the principles of group dynamics (group think, group polarization, influence, and power) and adapt processes as needed. 
 Employ conflict resolution/management/mediation skills appropriately. 
 Use summarization and synthesis methods to check group and individual understanding. 
 Guide the group toward brainstorming solutions. 
 Help the group consider tensions, trade-offs, and priorities among potential solutions. 
 Employ variety of decision-making process as needed to fit the group and issue. 
 Recognize when and how to transition the group from dialogue to action, if/when appropriate. 
 Recognize and plan for on-going dialogue in the face of change. 
 
 
 VI. \xc2\xa0Dialogue to Action 
 In some instances, dialogue that results in common and shared understanding may be an end goal by itself.\xc2\xa0 However, often dialogue on challenging issues will lead toward collective community action to address or respond to an issue.\xc2\xa0 During this time, maintaining the open, connected, and exploratory atmosphere created during the dialogue phase is vital to community progress and trust-building. 
 
 Guide the group through the process of identifying community assets that may support efforts moving forward. 
 Help the group set and work toward reasonable goals. 
 Guide groups in developing and implementing action plans. 
 Encourage community members to embrace leadership opportunities to take action and support their work. 
 Track, report, and celebrate progress. 
 
 
 VII. \xc2\xa0Cultural Competencies 
 Creating space for civil dialogue within our diverse and complex society requires acknowledgement and understanding of cultural differences as well as sensitivity for how to bring diverse individuals and groups together so that productive dialogue can occur. 
 
 Understand foundational issues that are sometimes present in multi-cultural dialogue and the need to address these, either in planning or directly with participants. \xc2\xa0Examples of these foundational issues are: \xc2\xa0assimilation,\xc2\xa0bias,\xc2\xa0discrimination,\xc2\xa0equality,\xc2\xa0equity, implicit bias, institutional racism, integration, micro aggressions, oppression, power, social identity, social justice, and white privilege. 
 Acknowledge history of and current state of oppression of various cultural and ethnic groups (racial trauma, violence, etc.) and how those differ from familiar dominant narratives. 
 Demonstrate understanding of how to work with diverse audiences (relate to, understand, adapt programming, and promote partnering, etc.) 
 Present information in non-judgmental way to help people grow and mature through dialogue process. 
 Recognize elements of culture dynamics such as development, values, beliefs, etc. 
 Identify myths, stereotypes, perceptions, and biases and work to effectively understand and overcome them. 
 Facilitate meaningful discussions that differentiate between tolerance, acceptance, appreciation and celebration. 
 Understand the needs of groups/voices that are marginalized and underrepresented (identifying, recruiting to the table, and creating safe/trusting space for participation). 
 Identify common values or interests among groups. 
 Understand and communicate multiple perspectives on challenging issues. 
 Create process that is inclusive and values differences 
 
 
 VIII. \xc2\xa0Other Kinds of Diversity 
 
 Understand how to work with different personality types in group settings. 
 Adapt processes to allow for participation of those with differing learning styles. 
 Manage groups that may involve different skill levels in dialogue. 
 Understand and adapt efforts to meet the needs of communities at risk. 
 
 
 IX. \xc2\xa0 Emotional Intelligence and Management 
 Topics and issues well suited to civil dialogue are often emotionally charged with strongly held views from multiple perspectives.\xc2\xa0 Facilitators must be able to manage emotional responses as well as coach participants in productive management of emotion. 
 
 Demonstrate ability to regulate one\xe2\x80\x99s own emotion as well as assist others, especially in moments of high tension 
 Recognize that feelings/emotions are an important way of knowing and experiencing the world alongside factually-based information and expert knowledge. 
 Create processes that encourage and invite all emotions into the space as source of healing and transformation 
 
 
 X. \xc2\xa0Facilitator Attitude and Disposition 
 To facilitate civil dialogue, especially on race relations, one must have certain attitudes and dispositions in order to convene diverse people for civil dialogue. 
 
 Approach facilitation with open-mindedness and humility that allows one to serve as neutral and objective facilitator of dialogue. 
 Maintain respect for diverse individuals and positions by having patience for how dialogue participants might engage in civil dialogue while striving for credibility and trustworthiness in how issues are discussed. 
 Demonstrate willingness and ability to listen to understand. 
 Exercising care to ensure that one\xe2\x80\x99s own conversation promotes positive interactions such as avoiding trigger words or concepts that may hinder conversations. 
 Have flexibility to modify processes and/or approach as necessary. Also recognize your own limits. Strive to create an environment in which individuals are comfortable and desire to understand one another and the issues discussed. 
 Have self-awareness about one\xe2\x80\x99s own culture, values, and biases and how they influence facilitation. 
 Maintain willingness to see the community as having valid knowledge and/or more knowledge than expertise from the university. 
 Be aware of one\xe2\x80\x99s own triggers while facilitating and have outlets for debriefing and decompressing around the challenging issues that arise in civil dialogue work across differences. 
 
 _____________________________ 
 References: 
 
 Hustedde, R. J. (1996). An Evaluation of the National Issues Forum Methodology for Stimulating Deliberation in Rural Kentucky. Journal of the Community Development Society, 27 (2), 197-210. 
 National Coalition for Dialogue and Deliberation. (2010). Resource Guide on Public Engagement. Retrieved from http://www.ncdd.org/files/NCDD2010_Resource_Guide.pdf 
 Peters, S. J. (2014). Extension Reconsidered. Choices: The Magazine of Food, Farm and Resource Issues, 29 (1), 1-6. 
 Shaffer, T. J. (2016). Looking Beyond Our Recent Past. National Civic Review, 105 (3), 3-10. 
 Singletary, L., Smith, M., Hill, G., Daniels, S., Smutko, S., Ayres, J., Haaland, K. (2007). Strengthening Extension\xe2\x80\x99s Capacity to Conduct Public Issues Education Programs:\xc2\xa0 Results of National Needs Assessment. Journal of Extension, 45(2).\xc2\xa0 Retrieved from https://joe.org/joe/2007june/a1.php 
 Wright, W. (2012). Wicked Bedfellows: Can Science and Democracy Coexist in the Land Grant? Higher Education Exchange 59-68.

						 Explore Extension Resources on Civil Dialogue 
					 

					 
						 
 The Rapid Response Team (RRT) on Civil Discourse was given as part of charge from the Extension Committee on Operations and Policy (ECOP) to identify and assemble set of resources generated from within Cooperative Extension Service that help promote civil dialogue on race relations.\xc2\xa0 The RRT gratefully acknowledges the wealth of resources suggested for inclusion in this list.\xc2\xa0 While this does not contain every resource that may be available nor does it address every element of the Competency Framework, these resources fit the following criteria for posting: 
 
 Materials were relevant to the topic: civil dialogue on race relations 
 Extension and/or other Land-Grant University professionals were authors or essential partners 
 Materials were easily accessible in some type of online format 
 
 In addition to these resources, explorers are encouraged to visit the Partners & Networks tab\xc2\xa0for links to vast number of non-profits and university centers/institutes with particular emphasis on this work.\xc2\xa0 Embedded within these sites is wealth of additional information and resources. 
 While the resources noted below all came as suggestions from within the Land-Grant system, the RRT did not vet nor review these resources for accuracy, but rather depended on the wisdom of the submitters for the validity of the content. 
 If you have resource you would like to submit for consideration that fits the criteria noted above, please visit the “Submit Resource” tab. 
 Resources 
 Each of the resources listed below is featured in short blog with additional information. \xc2\xa0Clicking on the links will take you to that information. \xc2\xa0Additionally, you can search by target audience or keyword.

				 Contact \xc2\xa0Walt Whitmer,\xc2\xa0wew2@psu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Effective community engagement seeks to better engage the community to achieve long-term and sustainable outcomes, processes, relationships, discourse, and decision-making in community-context sensitive environment.\xc2\xa0 Engagement is not generally driven by model so much as by framework of guiding principles, strategies, and approaches. This framework is based on principles that respect the right of all community members to be informed, consulted, involved and empowered and employs and range of tools and strategies to ensure success.\xc2\xa0 It also places premium on fostering and enhancing trust as critical element in long-term, sustainable engagement and effective governance. 
 The tools and resources provided here are intended to help you assess your engagement needs, plan for effective strategies and processes, as well as implement and monitor your engagement efforts.

 Description \xc2\xa0Nearly seven years of work to promote civic engagement in high poverty counties has led to rich insights into where and how this work thrives. team of researchers from across the South joined hands to synthesize the new understandings gleaned from these efforts.  Worthy, S. L., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Monroe, P., & Welborn, R. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Community champions as critical elements of success in turning around economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Dyk, P., Welborn, R., Worthy, S. L., Lowe, C., & Pickett, N. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Sustainability of community engagement in economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Welborn, R., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: The role of Cooperative Extension Service in the initiative, Community Development. 
 Welborn, R., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Documenting impacts through Ripple Effect Mapping, Community Development.

				 Contact \xc2\xa0Karen Pace,\xc2\xa0pace1@msu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0If you\xe2\x80\x99re involved with creating activities, camps and other events, be careful not to let your good intentions turn into potentially harmful acts of racism and exploitation. For example, what some see as cultural sharing (through costumes and crafts that involve American Indian symbols) others may see as cultural appropriation and acts of micro-aggression. But what\xe2\x80\x99s the difference between cultural sharing and cultural appropriation and why is this important? This article helps provide guidance. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/cultural_sharing_or_unintentional_racism

 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Youth leaders, Extension professionals

		 Contact: \xc2\xa0Liliana Vega,\xc2\xa0liliana@uidaho.edu 
 Description: \xc2\xa0The Latino community continues to grow at an increasing rate.\xc2\xa0 Latinos have become the “majority-minority,” and by 2043, minorities will be the majority in the U.S. with Latinos as the largest ethnic minority group.\xc2\xa0 The lack of targeted programming to ethnically diverse audiences is growing concern for many organizations.\xc2\xa0 This article describes research-based strategies and best practices for providing culturally appropriate Extension programs to the Latino community.

			 Annotated Bibliography of Structural Racism Present in the U.S. Food System 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report University professionals Food systems structural racism Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Rich Pirog,\xc2\xa0rspirog@msu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0This annotated bibliography provides current research and outreach on structural racism in the U.S. food system for the food system practitioner, researcher, and educator. Structural racism in the United States has been defined as the \xe2\x80\x9cnormalization and legitimization of an array of dynamics\xe2\x80\x94historical, cultural, institutional, and interpersonal\xe2\x80\x94that routinely advantage whites while producing cumulative and chronic outcomes for people of color.\xe2\x80\x9d 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://foodsystems.msu.edu/resources/structural_racism_in_us_food_system 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Food systems, structural racism 
 Target Audiences \xc2\xa0Food system practioners, Extension professionals, researchers, educators

			 An Evaluation of the National Issues Forum Methodology for Stimulating Deliberation in Rural Kentucky 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report hyper individualism National Issues Forum Public deliberation public dialogue Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Ron Hustedde,\xc2\xa0ronald.hustedde@uky.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Deliberation is implicit in the community development literature. Yet it is seldom addressed as topic in its own right. Deliberation is defined as the weighing of policy choices by the public. It involves critical thinking and open dialogue that creates sense of the public and the movement towards common ground. This article address the problems associated with deliberation: 1) hyperindividualism; 2) culture of limited public dialogue; and 3) the increased hegemony of science and technology. The National Issues Forum (NIF) methodology was employed as tool to overcome these problems of deliberation in rural Kentucky. naturalistic evaluation model was used to critique the application of NIF in rural settings. The ten lessons learned contain insights about the problems, successes and the limitations associated with the NIF methodology for stimulating deliberation. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://dx.doi.org/10.1080/15575339609489807 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0Public deliberation,National Issues Forum, hyper individualism, \xc2\xa0public dialogue 
 Target Audiences \xc2\xa0Extension professionals

			 Civic Engagement at Glance 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Elected or Appointed Leaders Extension Professionals Fact Sheet civic engagement collaboration discussion reflection Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Barbara Radke,\xc2\xa0radke008@umn.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0This publication, developed by Extension professionals at the University of Minnesota Extension Service, presents model or process of civic engagement. This model represents holistic approach to civic engagement that consists of five stages. These are: 
 
 Prepare 
 Inquire 
 Analyze 
 Synthesize 
 Act Together 
 
 Conveners and community are identified as the two partners in civic engagement. The five stages illustrate how conveners and community can move from launching deliberative work to implementation of specific strategies that address public issue. 
 URL: \xc2\xa0 http://www.extension.umn.edu/community/civic-engagement/engage-citizens-decisions/docs/civic-engagement-ataglance.pdf 
 Keywords: \xc2\xa0civic engagement, collaboration, discussion, reflection 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0community members, elected/appointed leaders

						 Partners & Networks in the Land Grant University System 
					 

					 
						 Through national survey conducted in late 2016, listing of centers, institutes, and teams from within the Land-Grant University System focused on civil dialogue with an emphasis on race relations was gathered. \xc2\xa0While the list may not be exhaustive, the following organizations were recommended for inclusion in the list. \xc2\xa0The first section below lists multi-state initiatives followed by university specific programs ordered by state, then university.

						 Submit Resource 
					 

					 
						 The Rapid Response Team (RRT) on Civil Discourse was given as part of charge from the Extension Committee on Operations and Policy (ECOP) to identify and assemble set of resources generated from within Cooperative Extension Service that help promote civil dialogue on race relations.\xc2\xa0 The RRT gratefully acknowledges the wealth of resources suggested for inclusion in the toolkit.\xc2\xa0 These\xc2\xa0resources fit the following criteria for posting: 
 
 Materials were relevant to the topic: civil dialogue on race relations 
 Extension and/or other Land-Grant University professionals were authors or essential partners 
 Materials were easily accessible in some type of online format 
 
 If you have resource you would like to submit for consideration that fits the criteria noted above, please visit [link to google form???].\xc2\xa0 Please note that each entry must contain the following information: 
 
 Title of resource 
 Key contact information 
 Short description 
 URL/ web address 
 Key words 
 Target audience 
 Person who is submitting the resource (you) 
 
 Click here to submit resource.

			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Resource Repository or Website Youth leaders bias harassment inclusion violence Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact: \xc2\xa0Janet Olsen,\xc2\xa0olsenj@msu.edu

			 The Language of Identity 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Extension Professionals Fact Sheet Individuals bias diversity inclusion language word choice Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Division of Inclusion, Diversity and Equity, University of Missouri,\xc2\xa0diversity@missouri.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Words can significantly impact our interaction with others. Regardless of our motive and intentions, they may harm or enhance dialogue. Learning about the most current terminology also encourages more productive dialogue about diversity and inclusion. Use this guide to begin learning about inclusive language. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 https://diversity.missouri.edu/education/handouts/inclusive-language.pdf 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0Diversity, language, word choice, bias, inclusion 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0Individuals, Extension professionals, community

			 April 10, 2017 Community Extension Professionals Fact Sheet Individuals bias diversity inclusion language word choice Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Division of Inclusion, Diversity and Equity, University of Missouri, diversity@missouri.edu

			 Guide to Facilitating Dialogues 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Extension Professionals Fact Sheet Individuals bias diversity inclusion language word choice Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Division of Inclusion, Diversity and Equity, University of Missouri,\xc2\xa0diversity@missouri.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Dialogue facilitators do not need to be experts on the topic being discussed. Good facilitators help establish safe environment where participants can discuss complex and often emotionally-charged issues. Facilitators also help participants understand that the dialogue is learning experience and not forum for participants to voice their opinions without listening to others.\xc2\xa0 This short fact sheet provides some initial thoughts to guide facilitator. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 https://diversity.missouri.edu/education/handouts/facilitating-dialogue.pdf 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0diversity, language, word choice, bias, inclusion 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0individuals, Extension professionals, community

			 Journal of the Community Development Society Special Issue: Turning the Tide on Poverty 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report University professionals champions civic engagement poverty race relations ripple mapping Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Rachel Welborn, Rachel.welborn@msstate.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Nearly seven years of work to promote civic engagement in high poverty counties has led to rich insights into where and how this work thrives. team of researchers from across the South joined hands to synthesize the new understandings gleaned from these efforts. The results are now published in special issue of the Journal of the Community Development Society, published in July 2016.\xc2\xa0 Articles in the Journal include: 
 
 Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Welborn, R., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: History, theoretical frameworks, and methods, Community Development. 
 Tyler-Mackey, C., Monroe, P., Dyk, P. Welborn, R., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Community climate in economically distressed rural communities, Community Development. 
 Worthy, S. L., Tyler-Mackey, C., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., & Welborn, R. (in review). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Perception of leaders and leadership in economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Worthy, S. L., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Monroe, P., & Welborn, R. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Community champions as critical elements of success in turning around economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Dyk, P., Welborn, R., Worthy, S. L., Lowe, C., & Pickett, N. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Sustainability of community engagement in economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Welborn, R., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: The role of Cooperative Extension Service in the initiative, Community Development. 
 Welborn, R., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Documenting impacts through Ripple Effect Mapping, Community Development. 
 
 URL :\xc2\xa0 http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/rcod20/47/3?nav=tocList 
 Program site:\xc2\xa0 http://srdc.msstate.edu/tide/ 
 Keywords :\xc2\xa0 Civic engagement, poverty, ripple mapping, race relations, champions 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0 University personnel, Extension professionals

			 Civic Engagement at Glance 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Elected or Appointed Leaders Extension Professionals Fact Sheet civic engagement collaboration discussion reflection Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Barbara Radke,\xc2\xa0radke008@umn.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0This publication, developed by Extension professionals at the University of Minnesota Extension Service, presents model or process of civic engagement. This model represents holistic approach to civic engagement that consists of five stages. These are: 
 
 Prepare 
 Inquire 
 Analyze 
 Synthesize 
 Act Together 
 
 Conveners and community are identified as the two partners in civic engagement. The five stages illustrate how conveners and community can move from launching deliberative work to implementation of specific strategies that address public issue. 
 URL: \xc2\xa0 http://www.extension.umn.edu/community/civic-engagement/engage-citizens-decisions/docs/civic-engagement-ataglance.pdf 
 Keywords: \xc2\xa0civic engagement, collaboration, discussion, reflection 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0community members, elected/appointed leaders 
	 
	
	 
					 
				 Leave comment 			 
		
			 
 
							
 
	 
		
				 
			 Family Leadership Training Institute (FLTI) 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Curriculum or Guide Individuals civic engagement family leadership Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact: \xc2\xa0Kyle Christensen,\xc2\xa0kyle.christensen@colostate.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0The Family Leadership Training Institute (FLTI), located at Colorado State University, is public-private partnership that works with local communities to provide parents/youth/communities with the knowledge, skills and tools for civic engagement. The goals of FLTI are to effect positive family leadership development by: 
 
 Helping families become leaders in their communities through civic engagement; 
 Expanding and facilitating the capacity of families to be change agents on neighborhood, regional and state level; 
 Developing supportive communities of families within regions of the state; 
 Facilitating family involvement in state and local policy decision-making processes; 
 Increasing parent-child interaction through family involvement. 
 
 FLTI offers 20-week program that integrates personal and child development, leadership training, civic literacy and civic participation skills. The curriculum for this program includes four components: an initial retreat; two 10-week sessions that focus on knowledge about the change process, skill building, tools of civic engagement, and community project. 
 URL: 
 www.coloradofamilyleadership.com 
 https://flti.wordpress.com/ 
 Keywords: \xc2\xa0civic engagement, family leadership 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0Individuals, community 
 The target audience for FLTI is to have diverse background and reflect the demographics of the community, i.e. various ages/ethnicity/income/education levels/etc.

			 40 Resources Posted 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals University professionals civil dialogue race relations resources Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Working from recommendations from Extension professionals across the country, the Rapid Response Team has identified 40 resources that seem to be well-suited to the work of civil dialogue around race relations. \xc2\xa0A short blog is posted about each one and provides brief overview of the resource, contact information, target audience, and URL. \xc2\xa0 You can browse these by scrolling through the blog posts or by going to the “Explore Resources” tab for listing that links the resources to their respective blog posts. \xc2\xa0Also, if you have resource to list, see the tab for instructions on making recommendation.

			 Community Engagement Toolbox 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Elected or Appointed Leaders Extension Professionals Individuals Resource Repository or Website Community engagement Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Walt Whitmer,\xc2\xa0wew2@psu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Effective community engagement seeks to better engage the community to achieve long-term and sustainable outcomes, processes, relationships, discourse, and decision-making in community-context sensitive environment.\xc2\xa0 Engagement is not generally driven by model so much as by framework of guiding principles, strategies, and approaches. This framework is based on principles that respect the right of all community members to be informed, consulted, involved and empowered and employs and range of tools and strategies to ensure success.\xc2\xa0 It also places premium on fostering and enhancing trust as critical element in long-term, sustainable engagement and effective governance. 
 The tools and resources provided here are intended to help you assess your engagement needs, plan for effective strategies and processes, as well as implement and monitor your engagement efforts. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://aese.psu.edu/research/centers/cecd/engagement-toolbox 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0community engagement 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0Individuals, Community, Elected/appointed leaders, Extension professionals 
	 
	
	 
					 
				 Leave comment 			 
		
			 
 
							
 
	 
		
				 
			 Engagement Toolbox 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Curriculum or Guide Elected or Appointed Leaders Extension Professionals Community engagement managing conflict trust Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Bill Shuffstall, wcs2@psu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0The Community Engagement Tool, developed and supported by the Center for Economic and Community Development at Penn State University, provides brief and practical guide to the major concepts, considerations, tools, and strategies to develop an effective engagement effort. The tools and resources are intended to help users assess engagement needs, plan for effective strategies and processes, as well as implement and monitor engagement efforts.\xc2\xa0 Topics addressed by the toolbox include key actions such as Establishing Your Engagement Goals, The Role and Importance of Building Trust, Facilitating Community Engagement, and Evaluating Engagement Efforts. The main idea of each topic is provided, as well as resources, and worksheets. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://aese.psu.edu/research/centers/cecd/engagement-toolbox 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0Community engagement, trust, managing conflict 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0community members, Elected/appointed leaders, Extension professionals

			 Strengthening Your Facilitation Skills 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Curriculum or Guide Elected or Appointed Leaders Extension Professionals Community facilitation Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contacts 
 Martha Walker,\xc2\xa0walker53@vt.edu 
 Crystal Tyler Mackey,\xc2\xa0cmtyler@vt.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Strengthening Your Facilitation Skills is facilitation training developed by Extension specialists with Virginia Cooperative Extension to help participants learn how to facilitate discussions that result in planning and clear direction. Specifically the 2- or 3-day training helps develop skills in dealing with challenges common to groups, and techniques to help lead group discussion on problem solving when dealing with sensitive issues or conflict. Training participants have the opportunity to: 
 
 Learn core facilitation competencies, 
 Observe facilitation challenges such as constant change, competing priorities, changing team members, limited time and carefully guarded resources, 
 Practice skills in an experimental setting and receive feedback in safe environment, and 
 Commit to build community capacity by volunteering facilitation skills to community group or organization. 
 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://www.ext.vt.edu/community-leadership/leadership.html 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0facilitation, community 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0 citizens, elected/appointed leaders, Extension professionals 
	 
	
	 
					 
				 Leave comment 			 
		
			 
 
							
 
	 
		
				 
			 Cultivating Community Conversations for Change 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Curriculum or Guide Individuals Community conversation facilitation invitation social fabric training Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Jody Horntvedt,\xc2\xa0hornt001@umn.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Cultivating Community Conversations for Change (C4) is new program which consists of series of events (trainings, community conversations, and regional forum) designed to engage community members in conversations to deepen their knowledge of community demographics, identify strengths and opportunities, explore resources, and develop strategies for community change. Core to this program are training events which invite leadership program alumni from multiple counties to enhance their skills for extending invitations to new audiences, hosting conversations, and building the social fabric of community. Community conversations center around study circle topics from Everyday Democracy (www.everyday-democracy.org) selected by communities on one of these topics: Building Healthier Community, Marketing Hometown America, Changing Faces Changing Communities, Facing Racism in Diverse Nation, One Nation Many Beliefs, Thriving Communities (a discussion of poverty), and Toward More Perfect Union. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 https://drive.google.com/file/d/0ByBEuE-gc-eLMjM3SlFOT2tmZ3c/view?usp=sharing 
 Keywords: \xc2\xa0community, conversation, invitation, social fabric, facilitation, training 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0 Individuals, Community

			 April 10, 2017 College Students Extension Professionals Resource Repository or Website Youth cultural competency dialogue diversity Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Academic Advancement Network, Michigan State University,\xc2\xa0AANcord@mus.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0The climate in the classroom has the potential to be difficult at various points of semester. This resource repository provides links to materials on racism, bias, dialogues, and host of other relevant topics.\xc2\xa0 The resources on this page were curated with the collaboration of Paulette Granberry-Russell of the Office for Inclusion and Intercultural Initiatives, Melissa McDaniels of The Graduate School, and Jim Lucas of the Office of the Associate Provost of Undergraduate Education. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://aan.msu.edu/opportunities/resources-difficult-dialogues

 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0college, high school, Extension Professionals

			 Navigating Difference 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Curriculum or Guide Extension Professionals cultural competency diversity Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contacts 
 Mary Deen,\xc2\xa0mdeen@wsu.edu 
 Merrianneeta Nesbitt,\xc2\xa0mnesbit@wsu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Navigating Difference (ND), developed by Washington State University Extension (WSUE), is cultural competency training based on the WSUE Cultural Competencies and is designed to help participants expand their skills in working with diverse audiences.\xc2\xa0 The overarching goals for the training are to assist participants to: 
 
 Become more aware of their own personal and organizational culuture; 
 Examine how their personal and organizational cultures affect their ability to work across difference in both negative and positive ways; 
 Build skills to increase competencies in working with others who are different. 
 
 Navigating Differences\xc2\xa0is comprised of five training modules, one on each of the following (a) cultural awareness, (b) cultural understanding, (c) cultural knowledge, (d) cultural interaction, and (e) cultural sensitivity.\xc2\xa0 ND is meant to be delivered face-to-face, and the total training is 18 hours. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://extension.wsu.edu/diversity/navigating-difference-training/ 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0cultural competency, diversity 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0 Extension personnel, community partners

			 Cultural Sharing or Unintentional Racism? 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report Youth leaders cultural programs exploitation microaggression Racism Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Karen Pace,\xc2\xa0pace1@msu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0If you\xe2\x80\x99re involved with creating activities, camps and other events, be careful not to let your good intentions turn into potentially harmful acts of racism and exploitation. For example, what some see as cultural sharing (through costumes and crafts that involve American Indian symbols) others may see as cultural appropriation and acts of micro-aggression. But what\xe2\x80\x99s the difference between cultural sharing and cultural appropriation and why is this important? This article helps provide guidance. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/cultural_sharing_or_unintentional_racism 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Racism, exploitation, cultural programs, microaggression 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Youth leaders, Extension professionals

			 Resources for Difficult Dialogues in the Classroom 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 College Students Extension Professionals Resource Repository or Website Youth cultural competency dialogue diversity Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Academic Advancement Network, Michigan State University,\xc2\xa0AANcord@mus.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0The climate in the classroom has the potential to be difficult at various points of semester. This resource repository provides links to materials on racism, bias, dialogues, and host of other relevant topics.\xc2\xa0 The resources on this page were curated with the collaboration of Paulette Granberry-Russell of the Office for Inclusion and Intercultural Initiatives, Melissa McDaniels of The Graduate School, and Jim Lucas of the Office of the Associate Provost of Undergraduate Education. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://aan.msu.edu/opportunities/resources-difficult-dialogues 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0cultural competency, diversity, dialogue 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0college, high school, Extension Professionals

		 Contact \xc2\xa0Work Group for Community Health and Development,\xc2\xa0 toolbox@ku.edu

		 Contact \xc2\xa0Cathleen Love,\xc2\xa0cathleen.love@uconn.edu

			 April 10, 2017 Community Extension Professionals Fact Sheet Individuals bias diversity inclusion language word choice Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Division of Inclusion, Diversity and Equity, University of Missouri,\xc2\xa0diversity@missouri.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Words can significantly impact our interaction with others. Regardless of our motive and intentions, they may harm or enhance dialogue.  Keywords \xc2\xa0Diversity, language, word choice, bias, inclusion

			 Guide to Facilitating Dialogues 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Extension Professionals Fact Sheet Individuals bias diversity inclusion language word choice Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Division of Inclusion, Diversity and Equity, University of Missouri,\xc2\xa0diversity@missouri.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Dialogue facilitators do not need to be experts on the topic being discussed. Good facilitators help establish safe environment where participants can discuss complex and often emotionally-charged issues. Facilitators also help participants understand that the dialogue is learning experience and not forum for participants to voice their opinions without listening to others.\xc2\xa0 This short fact sheet provides some initial thoughts to guide facilitator. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 https://diversity.missouri.edu/education/handouts/facilitating-dialogue.pdf 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0diversity, language, word choice, bias, inclusion 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0individuals, Extension professionals, community

			 WeConnect 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 4H Members Curriculum or Guide Youth 4-H citizen diversity responsibility Youth Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Jim Lindstrom,\xc2\xa0jlindstrom@uidaho.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0WeConnect is program model and curriculum designed to show young people that they are participants in global society and to prepare them to thrive in culturally diverse settings. The curriculum is developed for middle school-aged youth, but can be adapted for other age groups. The program model is designed for nonformal education setting such as after school programs or clubs. The lessons are coordinated series of experimental and interactive exercises that help guide youth beyond knowing that they are citizens of the globe to an acknowledgment of their responsibilities to each other and the world around them. They help youth examine their everyday lives and move them to take action that leads toward positive change. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://www.extension.umn.edu/youth/mn4-H/projects/leadership/global-connections/weconnect/ 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0diversity, youth, 4-H, citizen, responsibility, 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0Youth

			 April 10, 2017 children Curriculum or Guide children diversity Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Claudia C. Mincemoyer,\xc2\xa0cxm324@psu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Diversity activities teach young children to respect and celebrate the differences in all people. Learning about different cultural aspects offers new experiences for children. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://extension.psu.edu/youth/betterkidcare/knowledge-areas/environment-curriculum/activities/all-activities/we-are-different-we-are-the-same-teaching-young-children-about-diversity

			 People Empowering People 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Curriculum or Guide Individuals diversity parent leadership Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Cathy Love,\xc2\xa0cathleen.love@uconn.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0The UConn People Empowering People (PEP) program is personal, family and leadership development program with strong community focus. The goals of PEP are to help participants have greater understanding of personal strengths, increase their communication skills, and increase their understanding of and involvement in the community. PEP is delivered by an Extension-trained facilitator through 2-hour weekly sessions for 10 weeks. The curriculum includes sessions on values, communication skills, problem solving, parenting, action planning, community assessment, and community issues or related topics. Following the formal training sessions, participants will complete an individual and/or group project(s) that benefits the community. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://pep.extension.uconn.edu/ 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0parent leadership, diversity 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0Individuals,Community

			 Cultural Sharing or Unintentional Racism? 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report Youth leaders cultural programs exploitation microaggression Racism Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Karen Pace,\xc2\xa0pace1@msu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0If you\xe2\x80\x99re involved with creating activities, camps and other events, be careful not to let your good intentions turn into potentially harmful acts of racism and exploitation. For example, what some see as cultural sharing (through costumes and crafts that involve American Indian symbols) others may see as cultural appropriation and acts of micro-aggression. But what\xe2\x80\x99s the difference between cultural sharing and cultural appropriation and why is this important? This article helps provide guidance. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/cultural_sharing_or_unintentional_racism 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Racism, exploitation, cultural programs, microaggression 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Youth leaders, Extension professionals

			 Diversity: The Source of Our Strength 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 4H Members Curriculum or Guide Youth 4-H civil rights disabilities diversity inclusion leadership religion Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Jane Wright,\xc2\xa0wright.646@osu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0In this project, 4-H members explore the many forms of diversity in daily life, see life from various perspectives, and have fun learning about new situations and people who are different from them. The experience concludes with “capstone project” of the member’s choosing. In addition to addressing academic standards from the National Alliance for Secondary Education and Transition, the activities in the project build these life skills: valuing diversity, critical thinking, interacting with others, being empathetic, processing information, making decisions, and being responsible citizen. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://projectcentral.ohio4h.org/publications/diversity-the-source-of-our-strength/ 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0diversity, inclusion, leadership, 4-H, disabilities, religion, civil rights 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa04-H members, youth

			 Community Toolbox 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Community Elected or Appointed Leaders Extension Professionals Individuals Resource Repository or Website community organizing diversity facilitating needs assessment Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Work Group for Community Health and Development,\xc2\xa0 toolbox@ku.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Millions of people use the Community Tool Box each year to get help taking action, teaching, and training others in organizing for community development. Dive in to find help assessing community needs and resources, addressing social determinants of health, engaging stakeholders, action planning, building leadership, improving cultural competency, planning an evaluation, and sustaining your efforts over time. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://ctb.ku.edu/en 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0community organizing, facilitating, needs assessment, diversity 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0Individuals, Community, Elected/appointed leaders,\xc2\xa0Extension professionals

			 Journal of the Community Development Society Special Issue: Turning the Tide on Poverty 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report University professionals champions civic engagement poverty race relations ripple mapping Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Rachel Welborn, Rachel.welborn@msstate.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0Nearly seven years of work to promote civic engagement in high poverty counties has led to rich insights into where and how this work thrives. team of researchers from across the South joined hands to synthesize the new understandings gleaned from these efforts. The results are now published in special issue of the Journal of the Community Development Society, published in July 2016.\xc2\xa0 Articles in the Journal include: 
 
 Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Welborn, R., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: History, theoretical frameworks, and methods, Community Development. 
 Tyler-Mackey, C., Monroe, P., Dyk, P. Welborn, R., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Community climate in economically distressed rural communities, Community Development. 
 Worthy, S. L., Tyler-Mackey, C., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., & Welborn, R. (in review). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Perception of leaders and leadership in economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Worthy, S. L., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Monroe, P., & Welborn, R. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Community champions as critical elements of success in turning around economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., Dyk, P., Welborn, R., Worthy, S. L., Lowe, C., & Pickett, N. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Sustainability of community engagement in economically distressed communities, Community Development. 
 Welborn, R., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: The role of Cooperative Extension Service in the initiative, Community Development. 
 Welborn, R., Downey, L., Dyk, P., Monroe, P., Tyler-Mackey, C., & Worthy, S. L. (2016). Turning the Tide on Poverty: Documenting impacts through Ripple Effect Mapping, Community Development. 
 
 URL :\xc2\xa0 http://www.tandfonline.com/toc/rcod20/47/3?nav=tocList 
 Program site:\xc2\xa0 http://srdc.msstate.edu/tide/ 
 Keywords :\xc2\xa0 Civic engagement, poverty, ripple mapping, race relations, champions 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0 University personnel, Extension professionals

			 40 Resources Posted 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals University professionals civil dialogue race relations resources Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Working from recommendations from Extension professionals across the country, the Rapid Response Team has identified 40 resources that seem to be well-suited to the work of civil dialogue around race relations. \xc2\xa0A short blog is posted about each one and provides brief overview of the resource, contact information, target audience, and URL. \xc2\xa0 You can browse these by scrolling through the blog posts or by going to the “Explore Resources” tab for listing that links the resources to their respective blog posts. \xc2\xa0Also, if you have resource to list, see the tab for instructions on making recommendation.

			 Cultural Sharing or Unintentional Racism? 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Research Article or Report Youth leaders cultural programs exploitation microaggression Racism Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact \xc2\xa0Karen Pace,\xc2\xa0pace1@msu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0If you\xe2\x80\x99re involved with creating activities, camps and other events, be careful not to let your good intentions turn into potentially harmful acts of racism and exploitation. For example, what some see as cultural sharing (through costumes and crafts that involve American Indian symbols) others may see as cultural appropriation and acts of micro-aggression. But what\xe2\x80\x99s the difference between cultural sharing and cultural appropriation and why is this important? This article helps provide guidance. 
 URL \xc2\xa0 http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/cultural_sharing_or_unintentional_racism 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Racism, exploitation, cultural programs, microaggression 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Youth leaders, Extension professionals

			 Resources and Strategies for Addressing Safety, Understanding and Inclusion 
		 
		
		 
			 April 10, 2017 Extension Professionals Resource Repository or Website Youth leaders bias harassment inclusion violence Rachel Welborn 					 
	 

		 
		 Contact: \xc2\xa0Janet Olsen,\xc2\xa0olsenj@msu.edu 
 Description \xc2\xa0There are many tools available to help adults provide support to young people affected by bias, harassment and other forms of violence.\xc2\xa0 This website provides links to number of relevant resources. 
 URL: http://msue.anr.msu.edu/news/resources_and_strategies_for_addressing_safety_understanding_and_inclusion 
 Keywords \xc2\xa0Bias, harassment, violence, inclusion 
 Target Audiences: \xc2\xa0 Youth leaders, Extension professionals

							 eXtension Names Hill, Hino, & Stofer Fellows for 2015 
									 
							 Terry Meisenbach 
									 June 3, 2015 
												 Information 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Three eXtension Fellowships for 2015 will focus on Makers, Citizen Science, and the Internet of Things (IoT). eXtension Fellows come from Premium eXtension Foundation member institutions, spend one year devoted to their fellowship topic, present fellowship work and progress to CES throughout the year via LEARN and the 2016 National eXtension Conference, and develop user community or learning network around the topic. 
 The 2015 eXtension Fellows are: 
 Maker: Paul Hill Utah State University –Paul is an Extension assistant professor and 4-H agent in Washington County, Utah. His areas of expertise are: youth leadership, STEM education, volunteerism, social media, and small business development. Paul has been active in the maker community and is member of the eXtension Educational Technology Learning Network. Visit Paul’s eXtension Fellowship page 
 
 Internet of Things Jeff Hino Oregon State University –Jeff is the learning technology leader at Oregon State University working in Extension & Experiment Station Communications. He facilitates adoption of new communication and learning technologies and the OSU Ask an Expert initiative. He sees his role as one that empathizes with and encourages people as they begin or continue their relationship with technology. Jeff has an extensive background in instructional design, technology, and media production. He is also member of the eXtension Educational Technology Learning Network. Visit Jeff’s eXtension Fellowship page 
 
 Citizen Science Katie Stofer University of Florida –Katie is research assistant professor at the University of Florida in the Agricultural Education and Communication department. Her research focuses on Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM), especially in free-choice or informal education and outreach settings. She\xe2\x80\x99s interested in how the public gathers, makes meaning from, and uses current scientific research findings and how that use relates to their science identities. Visit Katie’s eXtension Fellowship page 
 For more information about the eXtension Fellowship contact either Jerry Thomas at jthomas@extension.org or Terry Meisenbach at tmeisenbach@extension.org.

							 2016 Innovation Projects 

						 
						 
							 Browse each of the nine Innovation projects funded in 2016 and visit their project page for more information. 
 Building Personalized Learning Experiences for Adult Learners through Adaptive Learning Techniques Michigan State University, Ellen Darnell and Gwyn Shelle This project will evaluate and pilot adaptive learning tools for future Cooperative Extension programming. The team of experts will research several existing adaptive learning tools and consult with experts in the field of online learning who are currently implementing adaptive learning into their programming. They will design and deliver adaptive learning activities within existing online courses through several selected pilot projects. Project page 
 Elevating of the Role of Spatial Reasoning in Communication and Decision Making in the Cooperative Extension System University of New Hampshire, Shane Bradt This project will empower CES staff to create interactive, online maps to collect and share spatial information, as well as, tell compelling stories. It will provide CES staff and administrators with access to relevant spatial data layers (i.e., census, political boundaries, watersheds, natural features) for their geographic region. It will advise Communities of Practice (CoP) and Learning Networks (LN) in the effective use of geospatial technologies in projects and grants. Project page 
 Extending Reality: Instant Access to Extension Resources Using Augmented Reality Innovations University of Tennessee, Heather Wallace and Emily Tipton This project will explore Augmented Reality (AR) to engage consumers in manner that will revolutionize daily life and transform research-based information access. This project is an innovation incubator to test augmented reality in consumers\xe2\x80\x99 daily lives and will serve as pilot in development and use of augmented reality software and existing content from eXtension and land grant institutions. While virtual reality \xe2\x80\x9ctests\xe2\x80\x9d possible scenarios, augmented reality applies solutions in real-time by projecting layers of data onto real world environments, creating deeper and more meaningful experiences for users. Project page 
 eXtension Geo-Citizens Design Forest Farms Virginia Tech, John Munsell This project accelerates Cooperative Extension\xe2\x80\x99s use of virtual high performance GeoDesign computing to improve the precision of farming systems in changing climate. The project advances Cooperative Extension citizen science 2.0 by bringing programmers, geospatial experts, land management specialists, and citizen scientists together in customizable, collaborative, and convivial virtual workspace to create precision agriculture computer application. The project enhances flipped and interactive Cooperative Extension remote training methods over broad geographical regions through novel synthesis of videography and problem solving scenarios. The project strengthens Cooperative Extension inclusivity with multi-institution, multi-state physiographic data collection and aggregation partnership. The project also demonstrates lasting NEW eXtension partnerships where computer simulation supports land use precision and citizens support computer simulation. Project page 
 Lighting the Education Fire with Virtual Environments and Oculus Rift Technology University of Idaho, Joey Peutz,\xc2\xa0Brian Cleveley and Lori Wahl This project proposes to extend Cooperative Extensions\xe2\x80\x99 outreach via 24/7 public experiential learning tools using the Oculus Rift virtual reality headset, web browser-based virtual environment (single and multi-user) and an app accessed through mobile devices supporting 3D virtual worlds. The primary demonstration project is simulation to learn about home safety when threatened by wildfire. The project offers the opportunity to experience wildfire safety experience as an immersive 3D simulation with participants customizing the experience variables. The ability to access the same simulation content across three different platforms is also new way of delivering knowledge making it more flexible and adaptable to meet the changing needs of Extension and their constituents. Project page 
 Track that Crop: Mobile App to Aggregate Crop Variety Data in Alaska and Beyond and to Increase Citizen Engagement with Cooperative Extension Service University of Alaska, Heidi Rader This project will create mobile app to conduct citizen agriculture research. Alaska Master Gardeners will help test the app followed by recruiting additional citizen scientists statewide and nationally. Extension\xe2\x80\x99s roots are in \xe2\x80\x9cextending\xe2\x80\x9d research-based information to the public. This project turns this traditional model upside down by asking the public to conduct and share research (also known as citizen science). The project proposes developing mobile app to aggregate location-based crop variety research conducted by Master Gardeners, gardeners, and farmers. Project page 
 NeXT Talks: Igniting Innovation in Extending Knowledge Texas A&M AgriLife Extension, Holly Whitaker This project expands platform designed to inspire innovation in Cooperative Extension program delivery by quickly connecting educators to material on emerging topics. These \xe2\x80\x9ctalks\xe2\x80\x9d are timely, proactive, interactive and position educators nationwide with information to position them as front line resources in their communities. Using streaming video and social media, NeXT Talks allow audience members to engage with subject matter specialists within and outside the land grant system. Project page 
 Spark Lab Innovation Center Ohio State University, Mark Light This project will instill that inspiration or \xe2\x80\x9cspark\xe2\x80\x9d that youth and adults need to learn, discover, and grow in creative environment. This goes beyond just setting up \xe2\x80\x9cmakerspace\xe2\x80\x9d. It will be an overall center of innovation framed through the education lens of land grant university system. This project will transform local Extension office beyond the traditional into the innovative by bringing entrepreneurship, university education opportunities, and technology and maker space together in dynamic and still to be explored relationship. The project will connect local businesses, residents, and educators to promote innovation, learning, and creativity in hands-on space. It will also create physical space model that can be reproduced by Extension in other states nationwide. Project page 
 Virtual Communication Camp North Dakota State University, Becky Koch and Bob Bertsch This project will prepare educator teams to focus on key messages and use innovative communication skills to plan communication strategy to help bring about behavior change. This project moves traditional face-to-face model to virtual learning experience especially designed to encourage teams to incorporate new and innovative technologies that meet their target audience\xe2\x80\x99s needs. Project page

							 i-Three Issue Corps: Farming the City: Utica 
									 
							 Bonnie Collins 
									 June 16, 2017 
												 Information 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Diverse individuals growing self-sufficient communities 
 Can farming in city get communities to self-sufficiency? No, but it is the place to start. This blog post is to share journey and belief that when we are responsible for providing food to share with community members it brings that community, as well as individuals, level of satisfaction. 
 
 When individuals from diverse backgrounds, diverse cultures, and diverse communities are satisfied, how does it affect the health and well-being of those communities? Community well-being includes the social, economic, environmental, cultural, and political conditions of individuals to fulfill their potential. 
 Contributors to project of bringing farming to Utica are community-based and interested in community gardening and share similar vision: that if we provide the education, support, and have community \xc2\xa0commitment to farm in the city, it will provide the first steps for community members\xe2\x80\x99 satisfaction and well-being. 
 
 Utica is one of two cities located in central New York in Oneida County. Our county is rich and diverse in agriculture. \xc2\xa0According to demographic report from Headwaters Economic Profile System https://headwaterseconomics.org/tools/economic-profile-system/ ), Utica\xe2\x80\x99s population was 61,628 in 2015. The population demographic is: \xc2\xa0Whites, 59.8%, African Americans, 14.7%, Asian Americans, 9.9%, and Hispanics or Latinos,11.4% with the balance made up of refugees. \xc2\xa0The largest groups ever resettled to Utica include Bosnian, Burmese, individuals from the former Soviet Union, and Vietnamese https://www.mvrcr.org/about/populations/ 
 One refugee said, \xc2\xa0\xe2\x80\x9cThere is this kind of depression. \xc2\xa0Everyone was dreaming to come to the U.S.A., but they were not happy. The people were put in apartments, missing activity, community. They were bored. They were homesick for traditional food, grown by hand, and many of the residents live at or below the poverty level.\xe2\x80\x9d 
 Utica has 32.2% of its population below the poverty line. Poverty is an important indicator of economic well-being. Individuals with limited income may have different values and attitudes as they related to their communities. 
 
 Fundamentally, community gardening is shared endeavor providing opportunities for members to improve their environments and/or produce fruit and vegetables for food. \xc2\xa0Community gardens have potential to improve nutritional status, increase physical activity, play role in reducing stress and promote better mental health all while contributing to an enhanced quality of life for those involved. 
 Our project\xe2\x80\x99s mission is to contribute to the evidence base that first-hand gardening activities play role in increased level of satisfaction both in individuals, as well as in their community. 
 Our next blog post will define the participants, define our partners and the types of quantitative and qualitative studies we will be conducting. \xc2\xa0

							 Connect With Sustainability-Focused Extension Programs Nationwide 
									 
							 Roslynn Brain 
									 June 27, 2017 
												 Information 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Are you interested in leading an Extension sustainability-focused program, but not sure what topics are already being covered? Do you want to learn who else is programming in this area so that you can learn from or collaborate with them? Perhaps you already are leading program but may be feeling alone in your efforts. 
 With the help of new\xc2\xa0 national database of sustainability-focused Extension programs connecting or getting inspired is made easy! Simply visit the database and discover over 170 entries with 41 states represented. Extension programs range from New York’s Consumer Education Program for Residential Energy Efficiency to New Mexico’s Master Composters program to Mississippi\xe2\x80\x99s Sustainable Bioproducts Initiative. 
 
 All entries in the database fall into one or more of the following categories: 
 
 Land (landfill and conservation issues) 
 Air (quality and climate change) 
 Food (sustainable and local food systems) 
 Water (quality and conservation) 
 Energy (efficiency and renewable). 
 
 In building the database, all states were contacted, sometimes several times. However, it is possible some programs were missed. If you do not see your program represented and would like to add it, there is an easy form that you can complete. 
 This project was made possible with funding provided by the U.S. Department of Agriculture:\xc2\xa0 National Institute of Food and Agriculture the\xc2\xa0 National Network for Sustainable Living Education \xc2\xa0and\xc2\xa0 Utah State University (USU) Extension Sustainability States were contacted and entries were formatted by USU Extension Sustainability intern Claire Core and associate professor Roslynn Brain. 
 To connect with other Extension professionals working on sustainability, visit the National Network for Sustainable Living Education

							 i-Three Issue Corps: We are the cultivators of our work environment 
									 
							 Christy Mannering 
									 June 29, 2017 
												 Diversity & Inclusion 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Recently, at the University of Delaware, had the opportunity to attend their first diversity summit, titled “ Diversity Summit: Realizing Social Justice for Better UD .” As member of the College of Agriculture and Natural Resources Diversity Committee, feel it is important to stay developed in this field, but didn’t know what to expect from an all-day summit and wasn’t sure how it would integrate with my role at UD or with the Diversity & Inclusion Issue Corps. 
 There were two keynote speakers Dr. Carol Henderson Vice Provost for Diversity at the University of Delaware, and Dr. Tony Allen recently appointed provost at Delaware State University. Dr. Carol Henderson spoke about our responsibility to making sure youth get quality educational experience. She said it takes all of us to cultivate that experience. would like to take that step forward, because believe this goes beyond the classroom. believe as professionals it is up to all of us us to cultivate the experience we have in our workplace. 
 Dr. Tony Allen speaking at UD Diversity Summit (Photo Credit: Christy Mannering) 
 During Dr. Tony Allen’s remarks, he said, “We all have responsibility to serve as we have been served. None of us white, black, brown, gay or straight, male or female, have gotten to any of our positions or any of our places in life, alone.” The truth is that whether we notice and acknowledge each other or not, we still all play role in each others lives. The way we live, the way we work, the way we present ourselves, our action and our inaction can very much impact and shape the lives of the people around us. 
 We impact and shape the lives of the people around us.\xc2\xa0 moment of clarity during the event realized how this connected with the idea of developing emotional intelligence in the workplace. If you’re stressed, overwhelmed or frustrated and you are unable to self-regulate that could negatively impact your work environment (Deleon, 2015). Our technical skills, our expertise and knowledge won’t matter if we are unable to effectively work with others. Emotions often prompt the way we behave and react. Our emotions influence the type of leader we are and how we learn from constructive criticism. 
 Emotional intelligence goes beyond self-awareness and self-regulation. Are we able to look through the lens of other people? Can we look through the lens of different backgrounds including age, culture, race and ability? To promote diversity and be inclusive we need to be aware of ourselves, aware of our peers and that includes colleagues outside our work “silos”. Being more in tune to each other will help us to provide better service to those we work with in the public and better workplace experience. 
 Sources: 
 Deleon, Mariah. (2015). “The Importance of Emotional Intelligence at Work.” Entrepreneur. https://www.entrepreneur.com/article/245755 
Diversity Summit Logo created by Office of Communication and Marketing at the University of Delaware

Her research interests include issues of social justice, such as nutritional insecurity, community re-entry, and domestic violence. She also volunteers with her local school district and has deep passion for education policy, as she believes many social injustices stem from inequitable opportunities in education.

							 Mashing-up Platforms and Gaining Permissions: Our Diversity E-book Project 
									 
							 Brian Raison 
									 July 7, 2017 
												 Diversity & Inclusion Information 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Diversity: The Source of Our Strength. OSU 4H publication 372. 
 E-books are old hat. Right? There are numerous platforms upon which one may design, write, and offer content. But do these mash-up with your university\xe2\x80\x99s (or organization\xe2\x80\x99s) server? Do you need permission? Or do you go rogue (using different system)? 
 Here at Ohio State, our \xe2\x80\x9cOnline Project Book\xe2\x80\x9d team left the Feb. 2017 eXtension Diversity & Inclusion Issue Corps meeting with great excitement. With the help (and inspiration) of experts and colleagues from around the country, we successfully developed an initial content layout plan and began the design formation phase. 
 Our aim was simple: translating print version of 4-H Diversity project book to an interactive, online option. use \xe2\x80\x9ctranslate\xe2\x80\x9d purposely. We did not wish to simply transfer content. (That could be boring online!) Instead, we wanted to translate the spirit of the readings and activities into an interactive, online book that would engage and (hopefully) inspire. 
 Sound easy enough? Well\xe2\x80\xa6 
 Our main challenges began with the platform. OSU uses different systems (sometimes depending on what college your department is housed in). Then, there were permission issues. Some team members could not access the content that others had begun. What we thought would be an easy online sharing process turned out to cause quite delay in progress. 
 So what\xe2\x80\x99s to be done? 
 Start early! But mostly, involve your technical peeps. They can help you avoid platform and permission issues BEFORE they happen. Also, look for non-team members who may have interests in your topic or expertise in design and delivery. They can be life-savers, contributing both small and large ideas that propel you forward. Lastly, look for students or interns that might be available to assist. We got very lucky in finding some free student hours. It moved our project forward\xe2\x80\xa6 and perhaps more importantly, gave her very nice resume item! 
 We continue moving ahead and look forward to the launch. 
 Brian Raison, Jo Williams, Jane Wright
