							 Mining the Land-grant Knowledge Network 
									 
							 Anne Mims Adrian 
									 August 10, 2017 
												 Information 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Who in Cooperative Extension is working on the Zika virus? Who is working on water quality or drought mitigation? Who is solving problems of food deserts? What resources are used to support these Extension programs? What can educators and researchers learn from others who are working in similar areas? How is research intertwined in these programs? 
 Cooperative Extension professionals and Extension\xe2\x80\x99s federal partners ask similar questions – and it\xe2\x80\x99s not always easy or swift to answer these questions beyond state and regional boundaries. Having access to other programs, resources, and the people who are successful in creating and conducting Extension programs could hasten Extension\xe2\x80\x99s national progress by sparking and accelerating the spread of innovation within the system 
 Currently, we are working on Knowledge Network to link Land-Grant University researchers and Cooperative Extension educators, their work, and their resources. The network directory will assist USDA, Extension and Land-Grant professionals, educators, and researchers to discover and connect with each other, resources, and programs. It will highlight and link to key Extension system assets (e.g. people, white papers, journal articles, courses, presentations, posters, data, toolkits, and decision making tools). 
 goal is more connected Cooperative Extension workforce that is able to constructively participate in and facilitate in online and offline conversations that lead to personal and professional learning and to better local programming. There is no need for central unit to host the work of the system but rather system that enables discovery of Extension work by smartly linking to the work through an easy-to-use mobile interface. Our first pilot will include an e-book interface. 
 We are collaborating with Matthew Lange of IC -FOODS of the University of California to develop an ontology(ies) creating common language so topics can be sorted and discovered much like the way libraries use keywords to describe books and journal articles. Potentially, for any given program, national presence can be built and Extension educators and others can generatively build their programs. 
 Jeff Piestrak investigative fellowship provided vision of land grant knowledge network to serve as useful national resource. The development of knowledge network is also informed by Christian Schmieder’s and Justin Smith\xe2\x80\x99s eXtension Fellowships. Christian demonstrated ways to analyze large quantities of Extension impact data Justin is testing and demonstrating protocols, making eXtension and Extension information more open, accessible and linked to open research and data. 
 Our goal is to have proof of concept of this knowledge network before the end of 2017. \xc2\xa0 We will demonstrate the possibilities of connecting varied and distributed body of data and information resources and expertise, including presentations, formal and informal articles and online dialogues, and extension.org resource articles. Our first demonstration project will support the Food Systems Impact Collaborative. 
 Please comment on this article or send your comments and ideas to aadrian@extension.org 
 Graphic is taken from Pixabay \xc2\xa0(public domain)

			 			 Written by Anne Mims Adrian 
			 Anne Mims Adrian, PhD, is currently working with eXtension partners to develop proof of concept of Cooperative Extension and Land-grant knowledge network. She is also the Project Manager for assessing open access to research and data for Presidents United to Solve Hunger (PUSH), an initiative of the Hunger Solutions Institute at Auburn University. Anne had served as the eXtension Director of National Presence and Director of Programs, and for years served as the Social Media Strategist with the Military Families Learning Network. She also served as Co-leader of the Alabama Cooperative Extension System and College of Agriculture Information Technology Unit for 10 years. She has PhD in Management, Masters and Bachelors degrees in Agricultural Economics.

							 BeeWise is “Buzzing” Right Along 
									 
							 Jane Crayton 
									 August 15, 2017 
												 Grants Innovation Maker Movement 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 What happens when you mix citizen science, youth STEAM (science, technology, engineering, arts, and math) education, beekeeping, the Maker movement, and throw in little Internet of Things just for fun? 
 You get BeeWise one of eXtension’s 2017 innovation projects. 
 Since the project announcement, the BeeWise Apiary at the Pueblo Zoo was dedicated by Pueblo County Commissioners and dignitaries. This was done during an Earth Day event that also featured native bee exhibit by Colorado State Beekeepers Association, native bee habitat building activity and pollinator plant talk by Pueblo Master Gardeners. It also included beekeeping equipment demo by Pueblo County Beekeepers Association. short presentation about the BeeWise project and the successful funding of BeeWise through several distinguished grants were delivered to the engaged audience. 
 BeeWise also participated in pollinator events in June during Colorado Pollinator Month, hosting booth at local farmers\xe2\x80\x99 market where top-bar honey bee exhibit was on display with honey bee and native bee specimens. pheromone game using essential oils was played with children to demonstrate how honey bees communicate using pheromones. 
 The prototyping has been partially completed for smart hive kit, using Raspberry Pi and sensors donated from Spark Fun (more on that in future posts). Summer camps (also in future post) have started and we have identified candidate for paid Maker/Beekeeper position. The project has even gotten its own logo (see image, right). 
 hiring panel made up of CSU-Extension office staff, 4-H leaders, an AmeriCorps Service Member, and the Makerspace Librarian at the local library, held interviews for the Maker/Beekeeper position. We identified person to fill the position who will assist with the final build of the kits and lessons for using the smart hive, maintaining the BeeWise Apiary, and outreach to local youth through school enrichment and summer camps, demonstrating the kit and teaching pollination programs. 
 Partnerships and collaboration have really driven the success of this program. You might say, it has become “hive” of activity that brings together many not only many different innovative ideas but many different people. 
 For more information about BeeWise, contact Jane Crayton at craytonj@pueblocounty.us

							 Jill Heemstra

												 Newsroom 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Is your state experiencing change?\xc2\xa0 Change is hard! \xc2\xa0Do you feel change accelerating in your professional or personal life? Do you thrive on workplace change? 
 Join the Military Families Learning Network (MFLN) Virtual Conference to learn how to ADAPT to change, GROW your understanding of your capacity for change, and\xc2\xa0 THRIVE as you connect with colleagues facing similar challenges.\xc2\xa0Cooperative Extension professionals will find lots of great information to help navigate change at work and with their clientele. 
 Save September 26-29, 2017 to join the MFLN for free Virtual Conference on \xe2\x80\x9cLearning Through Change.\xe2\x80\x9d

							 BeeWise Summer Camps Full of Fun and Discovery 
									 
							 Jane Crayton 
									 August 25, 2017 
												 Information 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 Three Beewise summer camps were held this summer. The first session was held June 5-9, 2017 with enrollment limited to 10 youth ages 8-13 for each session. The Pueblo City and County Zoo hosts the 4-H STEAM Pueblo Apiary and provides space for our summer camps and family friendly pollinator maker series. Several 4-H youth and 4-H Leaders who have volunteered for the camps. The second session of BeeWise Summer Camp was held July 17-21, 2017 at the Pueblo Zoo, and the third session was held August 7-11, 2017. The camps have been huge success and have been completely full each session. 
 Figure 1. BeeWise Session 1: June 5-9, 2017 
 BeeWise summer camp is full of fun and discovery, as youth dissect flowers when they learn about pollination, play the waggle dance game when learning about honey bee navigation, and identify honey bee classes (queen, drone, worker) from the safety of their beekeeping suits. The first session of camp was special because the youth got to help install the weather station and learn about all the functions of the station and how it works and collects data. The youth also engage with the art of beekeeping from honey extraction to candle and lip balm making. 
 This camp provides 15 contact hours of STEM learning focused on engaging students in learning by doing and project based learning. We also engage the Maker aspect, as kids help make frames for the hive or help do some task for the apiary that needs to be done.\xc2\xa0 They also get to make BeeWise button that they can wear on their shirt or hat. 
 After the summer, we plan to demonstrate the smart hive at the Pueblo Mini Maker Faire in late October. We hope to have the project built out into full kit by early spring so we can implement few kits at local schools and community spaces in spring of 2018. 
 To learn more about BeeWise, visit the project page or contact Jane Crayton at craytonj@pueblocounty.us

							 Building Smart Beehive 
									 
							 Jane Crayton 
									 August 30, 2017 
												 Information Innovation 
																		 
		 
							 
						 
														 The BeeWise project has prototyped \xc2\xa0a smart beehive for the Pueblo Zoo BeeWise Apiary and hosted three youth summer camps This post (part 3) is about the research and development that led to the smart hives. 
 The smart hive will be demonstrated at the Pueblo Mini Maker Faire \xc2\xa0October 28, 2017 at the STEAM Pueblo booth. pueblo.makerfaire.com We hope to have the project built out into full kit by early spring so we can implement few kits at local schools and community spaces in spring of 2018. 
 Research and Development of the Smart Hive 
 Phase 1: Identify data collection needs 
 The first step we took was to address the needs of beehive monitoring and develop efficient data gathering methods. It is important to know the hives humidity and temperature along with weight. This provides information that can be used to schedule feeding cycles or added winterizing. Gathered by analog and digital sensors the hive data can be transmitted by microprocessor and made available on the web, allowing beekeepers around the clock access to hive stats. 
 Phase 2: Identify Technologies 
 Next, we identified technologies and open source Internet of Things (IoT) networks. There are several methods of monitoring and controlling data sources available on the Internet. The most common being .IO sites that connect to devices over the Internet. Some are open source and others have premium to connect and store data. With Wi-Fi connection collected hive information can be compared to other hive analytics. This can shed light on colony collapse disorder (CCD) by generating geographical footprint of hive health. 
 Phase 3: Prototyping 
 For the hardware, we conducted Raspberry Pi and Arduino Hardware prototyping and testing with software IoT dashboard connections. We established server connection and communication between devices. This allowed for the best compatibility and user experience. It also supports continued management and modification of the hive data collection processes for future applications.\xc2\xa0 The final phase of prototyping to test newly integrated technology for the second iteration of the project will be completed in fall of 2017. 
 Technology Discovery 
 Overview 
 We have identified specific hardware and software we believe will work nicely for the project, and we will be moving into the final phase of prototyping this fall. We tested several different open source software options including, Cayenne, Ada Fruit (beta), Free Board. Cayenne is the only IO that is working with all the sensors. 
 Finding the right library for the sensor has proven difficult as we had sensors from variety of vendors. We have found that we need to obtain more rugged sensors to probe into the hive, or we will need to 3D print some custom cages to protect the sensors. It may be easier to buy hat for the Raspberry Pi which is basically an expansion board with bunch of sensors already installed. 
 Figure 1. Arduino UNO and Spark fun Temperature and Humidity Breadboard test connections 
 
 Figure 2. Raspberry Pi 3B – Temperature and PRI Motion Sensor Breadboard test connection. 
 
 Figure 3. Cayenne Remote Connection Interface 
 
 Figure 4. BeeWise hive sensor data viewable in Cayenne 
 
 Figure 5. BeeWise Pi – Mobile application display of data from hive sensors 
 
 We built beehive sensor super to prototype sensor and microcontroller integration into the hive colony. We need to have proper ventilation for the electrical components without compromising the hive. 
 Additionally, we identified an expanded lesson potential and cost reduction in the total kit by using Raspberry Pi weather station.\xc2\xa0 We need to test if the Pi can handle the sensors for the hive and the sensors for the weather station or if we need an additional Pi to run the weather hat. We need to test is the Pi weather station is as reliable as the Davis Weather Vantage Pro we currently have installed at the zoo in the apiary. 
 We also took google earth image of the Apiary for location reference for the weather and sensor data when using the Cayenne IO. 
 Equipment List 
 Below is list of the technology used and tested so far, with list of options for additional sensor expansions. 
 Microprocessor: Raspberry Pi 3B Wi-Fi 
 OS System: Raspberry Pixel Debian Linux 8.0 Python 
Power supply (120 VAC to +5 VDC, 12 VDC to VDC USB converter) 
16 GB SD RAM card 
 Rpi Options: 
 Pi Sense Hat 
Pi Weather Station 
Pi Camera 
 Microcontroller: Arduino Uno USB 
 Sensors Options: 
 Temperature/Humidity Sensor(s) 
Lux Sensor 
Rain Gauge 
Sound 
Gyroscope 
Motion 
Camera 
 Scale: 
Load cells 
Load Cell Mounts (frame, rails, direct) 
Feet or rubber bumpers, metric bolts 
 Other: 
Weatherproof enclosure for electronics. 
Mounting hardware for boards and sensors. 
Power (AC, Battery/Solar) 
Internet (Ethernet, WiFi, Cell Phone Hot Spot)

							 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker Provides Wide Variety of Innovative Experiences 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker to Combine Maker Education, Data Science, Fitness, and Wearable Tech 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Ohio State University 
 
 
 Location: 
Columbus, OH, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Robert Horton 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 Key Words 
 Big Data 
 4-H & Youth 
Citizen Science 
Maker Movement 
Wearable Technology 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 The project features first-of-its-kind 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker kit with Arduino microcontroller connecting heart rate, physical activity, and temperature with capabilities of operating within the structure of the internet. The 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker is expected to generate large amounts of data from the various sensors, thereby increasing the necessity for quick aggregation of the data, and an increase in the need to index, store, and process such data more effectively. Overall, the project team envisions demystifying for youth the basic principles of technology design and data collection that can then be utilized and applied as Data Scientists to examine their own fitness behavior, customize their Bio-Band\xe2\x80\x99s data input to fit their physical profile, and compare their experiences with greater community of users. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 Production of the first 1000 units is complete and tested with firmware installed and working properly. I\xe2\x80\x99m now in the software testing phase of the project followed by the curriculum development and marketing phases. Our hard launch will be National 4-H week which is the st week of October.

							 4-H Maker Festivals and Tech Wizards Expand to Multiple States 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
 Expansion of 4-H Ohio Pilot-Tested Maker Festivals and Tech Wizards to Rural Areas in Multiple States 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 The Ohio State University 
 
 
 Location: 
Kenton, OH, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Mark Light 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 Key Words 
 4-H & Youth 
STEM 
Maker Movement 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 In 2006, the first Maker Faire was started in the San Francisco Bay area for makers to share with each other in public venue. Because Extension is in every state and in most counties, we are equipped to grow this movement into more rural communities. The 4-H motto, \xe2\x80\x9cmaking the best better,\xe2\x80\x9d includes the word \xe2\x80\x9cmaking\xe2\x80\x9d. Extension has history of hands-on learning and making for over 100 years, so we are primed to connect with these new audiences of makers. As the outreach arm of the University, Extension has an opportunity to not only provide access to information like it has for more than 100 years, but also to showcase through the maker movement the hands-on education we have been facilitating for years through 4-H. 4-H Making Festivals will combine the best of the maker movement with hands-on-learning. Extension staff will plan and implement five festivals in fall 2017 and spring of 2018. These will include youth from the STEM-focused 4-H Tech Wizards after-school program. These festivals will be replicated across the nation and at additional sites in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Indiana. 
 4-H Making Festivals will combine the best of the maker movement with hands-on-learning. Extension staff will plan and implement five festivals in fall 2017 and spring of 2018. These will include youth from the STEM-focused 4-H Tech Wizards after-school program. These festivals will be replicated across the nation and at additional sites in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Indiana. 
 Mark led previous innovation project – the Spark Lab Innovation Center

							 About Us 

						 
						 
							 The United States Cooperative Extension System, with funding from Cooperative Extension directors and administrators, and USDA-NIFA, shares resources and tools through eXtension that enables the Extension workforce to scale up its local and national impact. eXtension is an integral part of the Extension Committee on Organization and Policy (ECOP) as illustrated in the ECOP organization chart eXtension is organized as 501(c)3 non-profit membership organization. Its Board of Directors represents the five regions of Cooperative Extension ECOP, and USDA-NIFA. 
 Members are Land-Grant Universities paying an annual membership fee, January-December of each calendar year, based on each institution\xe2\x80\x99s federal assessment. 
 eXtension provides core set of services and tools to all Land-Grant institutions regardless of membership status. For example, USDA-NIFA AFRI grants are supported where applicable, regardless of whether the grantees are from member institutions. In addition, all citizens have access to the content on eXtension and the Ask an Expert tool. Members of the eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s Foundation receive additional benefits including special pricing and enhanced tools and services including participation the Impact Collaborative eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s flagship program. 
 Serving all Land-Grant Institutions 
 The eXtension national presence serves all Land-Grant Universities, regardless of membership in the eXtension Foundation. eXtension user accounts and some tools are available to anyone with .gov, .mil and .edu email addresses for no fee. These tools include: 
 
 question and answer application for groups focused on their specific topics,\xc2\xa0 extension.org 
 listing service for online events such as webinars,\xc2\xa0 extension.org 
 Publishing on\xc2\xa0 extension.org 
 Toolkits created by the Rapid Response Teams of the ECOP Program Committee. 
 
 eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s mission is to increase Extension professional\xe2\x80\x99s effectiveness in addressing issues of importance to the nation through fostering creativity and innovation in developing solutions and methods of work and advancing the visible and measurable impact of their work for the public good. eXtension provides both the general public and Extension professionals with up-to-date science and evidence-based information and education, as well as opportunities to collaborate, co-learn and co-create through its virtual network of more than 15,000 users system wide. 
 Serving Members 
 All Member institutions \xc2\xa0can participate in our flagship Impact Collaborative and use our Zoom webinar services. In addition, faculty and staff from premium member institutions can participate in Innovation programs and teach online using our learning management system and its competency-based tracking and reporting.

							 Proposal Support Requests 

						 
						 
							 eXtension supports USDA and other agency grant projects. We have unique system for engaging Cooperative Extension professionals to design and strengthen local programs and interventions to solve local, state, regional, and national issues. We also have online tools available to support local solutions. 
 All faculty and staff from eXtension Foundation Member institutions can participate in our Impact Collaborative and use our Zoom webinar services. In addition, faculty from premium member institutions can participate in Innovation programs and teach online using our learning management system and its competency-based tracking and reporting (campus.extension.org). 
 eXtension user accounts and some tools are available to anyone with .gov, .mil and .edu email addresses for no fee regardless of membership in the eXtension Foundation: 
 
 question and answer application for groups focused on their specific topics, ask.extension.org 
 listing service for online events such as webinars, learn.extension.org 
 Publishing on articles.extension.org 
 
 These free eXtension tools and services are subject to change based on funding and priorities of the eXtension Foundation. 
 CHOOSE LETTER TO DOWNLOAD AND PRINT: 
 If you need letter of acknowledgment to use eXtension free tools listed above, click here 
 If you are principal investigator at basic member institution and need letter of acknowledgment including the free tools plus Zoom public webinars, click here 
 If you are principal investigator at premium member institution and need letter of acknowledgment including free tools, Zoom, and competency-based learning management system, click here 
 If you have budget for additional services, including member-only tools, Impact Collaboratives, competency framework development, and innovation support, contact us at ceoassist@extension.org 
 Published April 17, 2017

							 Augmented Reality Innovations 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
Extending Reality: Instant Access to Extension Resources Using Augmented Reality Innovations 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 University of Tennessee 
 
 
 Location: 
 Knoxville, Tennessee, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Heather Wallace 
 
 
 
 Emily Tipton 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
This project will explore Augmented Reality (AR) to engage consumers in manner that will revolutionize daily life and transform research-based information access. This project is an innovation incubator to test augmented reality in consumers\xe2\x80\x99 daily lives and will serve as pilot in development and use of augmented reality software and existing content from eXtension and land grant institutions. While virtual reality \xe2\x80\x9ctests\xe2\x80\x9d possible scenarios, augmented reality applies solutions in real-time by projecting layers of data onto real world environments, creating deeper and more meaningful experiences for users. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 Apple iPad devices, combined with iOS app Layar, are key components to this project as they will serve as the vehicle for creating Augmented Reality (AR) experiences for users. The iOS devices will be deployed into counties across Tennessee to test this technology in the hands of Extension agents. Each device will be managed remotely using cloud-based Mobile Device Management (MDM) software known as Cisco Meraki. Meraki MDM enables IT administrators to implement new apps and settings for AR testing as well as manage and troubleshoot issues with the devices from the cloud. Augmented Reality apps, such as Layar, will permit state-level specialists to extend the shelf-life of traditional print publications by adding the option of updating the digital AR experiences that are attached to the static content as desired. For more information about Layar, please visit – https://www.layar.com/

							 BeeWise: 4-H Project Creating Internet-Connected Beehives 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
 BeeWise: 4-H STEAM Pueblo project to create Internet of Things beehives to collect and analyze data for citizen science 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Colorado State University 
 
 
 Location: 
Pueblo, CO, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Jane Crayton 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 Key Words 
 Internet of Things (IoT) 
 Citizen Science 
4-H & Youth 
STEAM 
Beekeeping 
Maker Movement 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 BeeWise aims to create robust beekeeping program which integrates quality STEAM (Science, Technology, Engineering, Art, & Math) education with Maker Education, Internet of Things (IoT), and Citizen Science. Pueblo has large agricultural community and there is growing interest in beekeeping. The BeeWise program will engage these new beekeepers with the technology and education to successfully manage their apiaries. Several schools with FFA programs have discussed housing their own bee colonies and participating in camps and special programs. 
 Additionally, the BeeWise program aims to educate the general public on pollinators through strategic placement of hives at the Pueblo Zoo and the Pueblo County Courthouse which will highlight the importance of pollinators by using data that is collected from the apiaries. This will allow the public to interact with the apiary locally using an iPad Kiosk or the internet. Professional development opportunities will be available for other Agents, Zookeepers, and Teachers at FFA program. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 Bees installed in southern Colorado’s first smart hive

							 eXtension Board of Directors 

						 
						 
							 eXtension is an integral part of the United States Cooperative Extension System through the Extension Committee on Organization and Policy (ECOP). This is illustrated in the organization chart of ECOP eXtension is organized as 501(c)3 non-profit membership organization. It’s Board of Directors represents the five regions of Cooperative Extension. 
 Vernon Jones, Chair 
Administrator, Cooperative Extension Program 
Langston University (1890 Region) 
 Dr. Vernon Jones is the administrator\xc2\xa0of the Cooperative Extension Program at Langston University. He has served at Langston University for more than 30 years, conducting\xc2\xa0research in the areas of double cropping, conservation tillage, relay intercropping, drought tolerance, adaptability of kochia as forage crop in Oklahoma and nitrate movement in the soil profile. He has previously\xc2\xa0served as supervisor for Cooperative Extension paraprofessionals, and an acting division director. He is member of the American Society of Agronomy and the Crop Science Society. 
 Jones\xc2\xa0holds bachelor’s degree from Southern University and A&M College, and his master’s and\xc2\xa0doctoral degrees in crop production from the University of Illinois at Urban-Champaign. 
 Jason Henderson, Vice-chair/Secretary 
Associate Dean, College of Agriculture and Director, Purdue Extension 
Purdue University (North Central Region) 
 Dr. Jason Henderson is vice president and Omaha branch executive at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City.\xc2\xa0He\xc2\xa0joined the Omaha Branch as branch executive\xc2\xa0in 2006. Prior to being promoted into this position, he served as senior economist with the Center for the Study of Rural America, also at the Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City. 
 Henderson holds bachelor’s degree in economics from Central College in Pella, Iowa and his master’s and doctorate degrees from Purdue University, where he was also\xc2\xa0the recipient of USDA National Needs PhD Fellowship in Agribusiness. 
 Doug Steele, Treasurer 
Director 
Texas AgriLife Extension Service (Southern Region) 
 Dr. Doug Steele has served as\xc2\xa0director of the Texas AgriLife Extension Service since 2012, following time of service as vice president for external relations and director of Extension at Montana State University. He served as AgriLife Extension agriculture program director in Hutchinson County, Texas in the late 1980s, before going to Texas A&M to work on his advanced degrees. \xc2\xa0There he was an Extension associate for community and economic development from 1988-90, and an AgriLife Extension 4-H youth development specialist and assistant professor from 1990-93. He also served at Purdue University and Colorado State University in 4-H specialist and leader positions. 
 Steele holds bachelor’s degree in animal science and agri-business from Panhandle State University, and both his master’s and doctorate from West Texas A&M University and Texas A&M, respectively. 
 Barbara Petty 
 Associate Dean and Director of Extension 
University of Idaho (Western Region) 
 Nebraska native, she moved to Idaho Falls in 1998 when her husband, Terry, was chosen to pastor congregation there. 
 After earning her bachelor\xe2\x80\x99s degree in vocational home economics education in 1977, she taught home economics in Missouri before focusing on raising her children. She earned master\xe2\x80\x99s degree in human development and the family from the University of Nebraska in Lincoln in 1984 and returned to teaching there in 1995. 
 After beginning work in UI Extension\xe2\x80\x99s Bonneville County office, Petty worked on other collaborative projects with fellow Extension family and consumer sciences faculty focused on nutrition and financial training. 
 As her interest in an Extension career grew, Petty sought additional education. In 2007, she earned doctorate in education with an emphasis in adult education and organizational learning from the University of Idaho. 
 Petty became director of the southern Idaho Horizons Project in 2008 and guided UI Extension\xe2\x80\x99s efforts to build leadership capacity in 15 communities through the program funded by the Northwest Area Foundation. In 2010, she became UI Extension\xe2\x80\x99s Eastern District Director and was named Statewide Director in 2016. 
 Ken La Valley 
 Dean and Director Cooperative Extension 
University of New Hampshire (Northeast Region) 
 From 2004 through 2010, he worked as Commercial Fisheries and Aquaculture State Specialist and Extension Faculty member. As an Extension Associate Professor he developed and implemented marine fisheries and aquaculture extension programs as well as conducted applied research, taught undergraduate courses (BIOL 411, ZOOL 412, ZOOL 503 and ZOOL 998) and advised undergraduate and graduate students in the Department of Biological Sciences. 
 He joined the Administrative Team in 2010 and has served as Program Leader, Associate Director for Programs and is currently the Dean and Director. 
 Jane Clary Loveless 
National Program Leader 
USDA-NIFA 
 ex officio 
 Jane Clary Loveless provides leadership to nutrition/extension education programs, the Nutrition and Health Committee for Planning and Guidance, Community Food Projects (CFP) grants, AFRI Childhood Obesity grant,\xc2\xa0eXtension Families Food & Fitness virtual education site, and the Food Insecurity Nutrition Incentive (FINI) Grant Program. 
 To Be Named 
Executive Director 
Extension Committee on Organization and Policy 
 ex officio

							 Christian Schmieder 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Christian Schmieder, University of Wisconsin 
 \xe2\x80\x9cResponding to the \xe2\x80\x98Data Imperative\xe2\x80\x99 in Extension:\xc2\xa0 Developing National Online Qualitative Analysis and Analysis Software Learning Platform\xe2\x80\x9d 
 Christian is Qualitative Research Specialist who serves as consultant to\xc2\xa0educators,\xc2\xa0researchers, research teams and leadership teams across the University. 
 Christian plans to assess the scalability of analysis-focused software training required to build proficiency among Extension professionals in using Qualitative Data Analysis Software to analyze large qualitative data sets. Building on the model developed in his unit at his home institution, University of Wisconsin, he proposes to develop working prototype for this training, including online materials and teaching modules that might be disseminated for national use.

 University of Wisconsin-Extension

 Madison, WI, USA

							 Coming Soon! Impact Collaborative for Food Systems Call for Applications 

						 
						 
							 Calling all Extension Professionals! If you work somewhere on the food systems spectrum and are excited about innovative approaches that make visible difference at the local level, this program is for you. Our goal for the 2017 eXtension Impact Collaborative for Food Systems is to identify 225 projects and work with around 700 Extension professionals and their partners. 
 The Impact Collaborative is the new name for the Issue Corps The Collaborative catalyzes the work of innovative Extension Professionals by supporting their efforts in several ways: 
 
 Organizing Designathon event to introduce design thinking and concept mapping to program planning 
 Providing access to mentoring from key informants in topics relevant to Impact Collaborative projects 
 Offering professional development around topics selected by Collaborative members 
 Amplifying Collaborative members’ efforts by sharing their work at national level to foster adoption of evidence-based approaches and practices throughout the Cooperative Extension System 
 
 This support, along with the dynamic synergy from interacting and networking with other Extension Professionals is designed to accelerate the adoption of innovation in local programming. 
 Timeline 
 The organizing committee will develop and release the call for applications this spring (2017). Professional development will begin in the summer with the Designathon planned for winter. Professional development, key informant mentoring, and building the knowledge base on evidence-based practices will continue after the Designathon. 
 To be sure to receive announcements when the call for applications is released, you need to be on the eXtension mailing list. If you do not already have an eXtension ID, visit the People site and signup 
 Issue Corps members must be part of an eXtension member institution. Review the list of current members to verify the membership status of your institution.

							 Dave Francis 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Dave Francis 
 Maker – Horticulture Fusion 
 Dave is an Extension Associate Professor and 4-H Youth Development Specialist at Thanksgiving Point. 
 Within the Maker Movement, there is new trend developing known as \xe2\x80\x9cgeek gardening.\xe2\x80\x9d It refers to gardening enhanced with technology-focused methods to increase the production of plant products or to solve issues such as irrigation or pest control. Geek gardening is particularly attractive to gardening enthusiasts interested in local, small-scale agriculture and growing in small urban environments. 
 related interest among these makers is \xe2\x80\x9cslow tools\xe2\x80\x9d\xe2\x80\x93appropriately scaled, lightweight, affordable and open-source tools for small-scale farmers. The focus of Dave\xe2\x80\x99s work will be to identify and showcase variety of innovators, projects, and solutions in the geek gardening arena and, using eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s outreach technologies, to introduce their innovations to gardening enthusiasts and small-acreage producers\xe2\x80\x93and also to tech enthusiasts to encourage them to turn their hand to horticulture topics.

							 eXtension Geo-Citizens Design Forest Farms 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
eXtension Geo-Citizens Design Forest Farms 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Virginia Tech 
 
 
 Location: 
Blacksburg, VA, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 John Munsell 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 Keywords 
 Mobile app 
 Citizen Science 
 Geospatial Technology 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
This project accelerates Cooperative Extension citizen science 2.0 by bringing programmers, geospatial experts, land management specialists, and citizen scientists together in customizable, collaborative, and convivial virtual workspace to create precision agriculture computer application. The project enhances flipped and interactive Cooperative Extension remote training methods over broad geographical regions through novel synthesis of videography and problem-solving scenarios. The project strengthens Cooperative Extension inclusivity with multi-institution, multi-state physiographic data collection and aggregation partnership. The project also demonstrates lasting NEW eXtension partnerships where computer simulation supports land use precision and citizens support computer simulation. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 After the first field test, the team traveled to West Virginia University to discuss their work related to forest ecology and growth characteristics of wild ginseng populations. The team gained valuable insights into key environmental considerations for the PlantShoe citizen science forest inventory protocol. 
 Most recently, partners took to the road again for two Forest Botanical workshops in Front Royal and Abingdon, Virginia to exchange information across the supply chain and establish grower-industry connections that could lead to contractual trade relationships.

							 Five Innovation Grants Awarded by eXtension – More Than 90 Proposals Submitted 

						 
						 
							 Five projects have been selected from more than 90 proposals submitted for funding through the eXtension Foundation Innovation Lab The projects span many of the topics highlighted in the recent Horizon Report 2016-2021 Cooperative Extension Edition and range from Makers, to geospatial technology, drones, Internet of Things, and more. The projects are listed below in alphabetical order of the principal investigator. 
 Empowering the Cooperative Extension System to make decisions with spatial data using the National Extension Web-mapping Tool 
 Shane Bradt, University of New Hampshire 
 The goal of the National Extension Web-mapping Tool (NEWT), created during previous eXtension Innovation grant is to increase the effective use of spatial data to make strategic decisions regarding planning and programming in the Cooperative Extension System (CES). NEWT is not simply way to add data layers to map, but instead is straightforward online tool for exploring spatial data relevant to CES in the ways which CES staff and administrators find useful, including maps, tables, and graphs. 
 Once NEWT is released publicly in late spring 2017, this Innovation Grant will focus on promoting NEWT throughout CES, offering professional development on the use of NEWT, and gathering feedback regarding the current version, including ideas regarding new functions and datasets which could further broaden the use of NEWT. Visit the project page 
 BeeWise: 4-H STEAM Pueblo project to create Internet of Things beehives to collect and analyze data for citizen science 
 Jane Crayton, Colorado State University 
 BeeWise aims to create robust beekeeping program which integrates quality STEM education with Maker Ed, Internet of Things (IoT), and Citizen Science. Pueblo has large agricultural community and there is growing interest in beekeeping. The BeeWise program will engage these new beekeepers with the technology and education to successfully manage their apiaries. Several schools with FFA programs have discussed housing their own bee colonies and participating in camps and special programs. 
 Additionally, the BeeWise program aims to educate the general public on pollinators through strategic placement of hives at the Pueblo Zoo and the Pueblo County Courthouse which will highlight the importance of pollinators by using data that is collected from the apiaries. This will allow the public to interact with the apiary locally using an iPad Kiosk or the internet. Professional development opportunities will be available for other Agents, Zookeepers, and Teachers at FFA program. Visit the project page 
 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker to Combine Maker Education, Data Science, Fitness, and Wearable Tech 
 Robert Horton, The Ohio State University 
 The project features first-of-its-kind 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker kit with Arduino microcontroller connecting heart rate, physical activity, and temperature with capabilities of operating within the structure of the internet. The 4-H BioBand Fitness Tracker is expected to generate large amounts of data from the various sensors, thereby increasing the necessity for quick aggregation of the data, and an increase in the need to index, store, and process such data more effectively. Overall, the project team envisions demystifying for youth the basic principles of technology design and data collection that can then be utilized and applied as Data Scientists to examine their own fitness behavior, customize their Bio-Band\xe2\x80\x99s data input to fit their physical profile, and compare their experiences with greater community of users. Visit the project page 
 
 Expansion of 4-H Ohio pilot-tested Maker Festivals and Tech Wizards to rural areas in multiple states 
 Mark Light, The Ohio State University 
 In 2006, the first Maker Faire was started in the San Francisco Bay area for makers to share with each other in public venue. Because Extension is in every state and in most counties, we are equipped to grow this movement into more rural communities. The 4-H motto, \xe2\x80\x9cmaking the best better,\xe2\x80\x9d includes the word \xe2\x80\x9cmaking\xe2\x80\x9d. Extension has history of hands-on learning and making for over 100 years, so we are primed to connect with these new audiences of makers. As the outreach arm of the University, Extension has an opportunity to not only provide access to information like it has for more than 100 years, but also to showcase through the maker movement the hands-on education we have been facilitating for years through 4-H. 4-H Making Festivals will combine the best of the maker movement with hands-on-learning. Extension staff will plan and implement five festivals in fall 2017 and spring of 2018. These will include youth from the STEM-focused 4-H Tech Wizards after-school program. These festivals will be replicated across the nation and at additional sites in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Indiana. 
 4-H Making Festivals will combine the best of the maker movement with hands-on-learning. Extension staff will plan and implement five festivals in fall 2017 and spring of 2018. These will include youth from the STEM-focused 4-H Tech Wizards after-school program. These festivals will be replicated across the nation and at additional sites in Ohio, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, and Indiana. Visit the project page 
 Integrating small unmanned aerial systems and precision agriculture with beef production systems 
 John McGee, Virginia Tech 
 The goal of this project is to introduce innovative technology that can be adopted by Extension, local producers, and other stakeholders to support increased efficiencies in ag operations, especially beef cattle production. The small unmanned aerial systems (sUAS) regulatory landscape changed dramatically with the FAA\xe2\x80\x99s revisions that took place over the summer, 2016. As result of these regulatory changes, Virginia Cooperative Extension (VCE) has been developing in-house expertise to support sUAS applications across program areas to support an array of needs by managers and producers. Precision agriculture is one of these potential application areas. 
 Based on findings from this project, VCE agents and specialists, as well as other stakeholders, will better understand some of the limitations, challenges, and benefits associated with the use of sUAS to support agricultural management. Using this information, we will be able to refine future programming efforts that can be used to support agricultural producers not only across the state but in other regions of the U.S. and beyond. Visit the project page

							 Getting Started 

						 
						 
							 The eXtension Foundation offers variety of ways to collaborate with peers around emerging Issues and Innovation to evoke Impact for Extension Professionals and the Public they serve. Start connecting by obtaining your eXtension ID or reviewing your account.\xc2\xa0 
 CONNECT WITH PEERS: Get Your eXtension ID 
 Obtain an Individual Account 
 
 Sign up for eXtension by filling out the profile at https://people.extension.org/signup 
 Review eligible account holders. If applicable, click the \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99m eligible, Sign me up!\xe2\x80\x9d button then fill in the required fields. 
 Even though it\xe2\x80\x99s not required, we recommend entering your preferred phone number, title, and time zone. 
 Click on \xe2\x80\x98Position\xe2\x80\x99, which makes it easier for people to find you for potential collaboration. 
 Under \xe2\x80\x98Location\xe2\x80\x99, click your state in the drop-down box. This then allows you to click on your county and your institutional affiliation. Please indicate your University so you become listed with others from your institution. 
 
 Forgot Your eXtension ID or Password? 
 
 Go to the log-in page at http://people.extension.org/, and click \xe2\x80\x9cForgot password?\xe2\x80\x9d You\xe2\x80\x99ll be asked to enter your eXtension ID or the email you used to register when you first signed up. You\xe2\x80\x99ll be emailed directions for resetting your password. 
 If you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what email address you used when you signed up, go to the sign up page at https://www.extension.org/people/signup and proceed as if you are signing up for the first time. If you use the same email you used before, you\xe2\x80\x99ll be alerted that you are already member. Then you can go back to step one and enter in your email in order to reset your password. If you don\xe2\x80\x99t know what email you used, click Contact Us at the bottom of the page and submit request for help. 
 
 GO EXPLORING! 
 Explore the tools and services eXtension offers to the Cooperative Extension System.

							 Track that Crop: Mobile App to Aggregate Crop Variety Data 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
Track that Crop: Mobile App to Aggregate Crop Variety Data in Alaska and Beyond and to Increase Citizen Engagement with Cooperative Extension Service 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 University of Alaska 
 
 
 Location: 
Fairbanks, AK, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Heidi Rader 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
This project will create mobile app to conduct citizen agriculture research. Alaska Master Gardeners will help test the app followed by recruiting additional citizen scientists statewide and nationally. Extension\xe2\x80\x99s roots are in \xe2\x80\x9cextending\xe2\x80\x9d research-based information to the public. This project turns this traditional model upside down by asking the public to conduct and share research (also known as citizen science). The project proposes developing mobile app to aggregate location-based crop variety research conducted by Master Gardeners, gardeners, and farmers. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 The Grow & Tell app has been released (March 2017).\xc2\xa0 The app crowdsources recommendations on vegetable varieties so that gardeners can see what grows best in their area. The app helps people in areas where vegetable variety trials may not be applicable. Read the University of Alaska Fairbanks news release… 
 The office of Intellectual Property and Commercialization at the University of Alaska Fairbanks recently awarded Heidi Rader an inventor award for the mobile app at the 2016 Invent Alaska competition 
 
 
 
 
 Recent Publications: 
 
 Grow & Tell app (available for Android and iOS) 
 How does Ask an Expert Stack Up against Stack Exchange\xe2\x80\x94A Crowdsourcing Approach to Answering Questions and Solving Problems – eXtension.org 
 
 
 
 
 
 Related Links: 
 
 Heidi Rader’s CV page 
 LinkedIn

							 Horizon Report for Cooperative Extension 

						 
						 
							 Welcome to the first Extension Horizon Report! The report focus on trends, issues, and developments over the next five years (the near \xe2\x80\x9chorizon\xe2\x80\x9d). team of 50 Extension professionals dedicated time as panel to review materials and create the findings of the report. It is our hope that the Report: 
 
 Serves as guide for policy, training, and funding decision making 
 Creates awareness around key trends, issues, and developments 
 Increases future thinking in the Cooperative Extension system 
 
 If you have questions or comments about the report please direct them to Dr. Jerry Thomas,\xc2\xa0 at jthomas@extension.org 
 NMC Horizon Report > 2016-2021 Cooperative Extension Edition 
 The inaugural Horizon report for the NMC Technology Outlook for Cooperative Extension 2016-2021 features nine key trends, nine significant challenges, and twelve important developments in education technology. Read about the projects, policies, and leadership initiatives that reflect these topics in action. 
 NMC Horizon Report > 2016-2021 Cooperative Extension Edition 
 Jamie Seger, one of the leaders of the EdTech Learning Network, developed two-page summary of the key points in the Horizon Report. Cooperative Extension Horizon Report Summary 
 Upcoming Learning Opportunities 
 To highlight extension programming work already being done in some of these innovative areas, variety of learning events are being planned to share learning to date, as well as to open up the conversation around how cooperative extension can use the technologies featured int he report. Plan to join in the learning opportunities, Web meeting or TweetUps, that meet your interested and availability. 
 



 

 
 Resources 
 In addition to the interactive learning opportunities, check out this curated list of resources that cover number of the important developments in education technology from the report. 
 Submit additional resources… 
 Do you know of additional people, programs, publications, and resources that should be included as resources useful to other Extension professionals interested in each of the topics on this page?\xc2\xa0Let us know! Complete this form to share. 
 Time-to-Adoption Horizon: One Year or Less (2016-2017) 
 Makerspaces 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Community The eXtension Makers Community in people.extension.org. 
 eXtension Fellow. Paul Hill Utah State University, Created the http://www.extedtechs.org/makers/ website 
 
 As part of Paul\xe2\x80\x99s eXtension fellowship, he curated list of people in Extension and allied agencies working in the Maker Movement and describes their programs. 
 
 Innovation Grant Mark Light Ohio State University 
 
 Hardin County, Ohio State University Spark Lab 
 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, getting started in creating makerspace, and including makers in Extension programming. 
 
 Paul Hill\xe2\x80\x99s curated list of resources on creating and programming with Makers 
 \xe2\x80\x9cLearn\xe2\x80\x9d listings (webinars) related to Maker Movement and to Makerspaces 
 Playlist \xe2\x80\x9c Maker Movement \xe2\x80\x9d, video \xe2\x80\x9c Building & Managing Makerspaces in Extension \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Journal of Extension articles on Makerspaces and Maker Movement 
 4-H Maker Resources 
 EdTechLN Tweetup, July 2016 Storify archive \xe2\x80\x9c Maker Movement in Extension \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Podcast \xe2\x80\x9c Working Differently Episode 73 \xe2\x80\x9d (Lenah Nguyen, Katie Thomas, Paul Hill) 
 Articles and blog posts on extension.org 
 
 Ten statistics that reveal the size and scope of the maker movement 
 What is the Maker Movement? 
 How Extension Can Serve the Maker Movement 
 
 
 
 Gaps 
 
 There are currently no courses on campus.extension.org related to makerspaces or the Maker Movement 
 There are few posts on extension.org & content on articles.extension.org on this topic 
 
 Mobile Learning 
 How are Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through mobile learning? 
 
 Learning resources designed and optimized for mobile delivery provide credible, discoverable information at the time and in the place it is needed keeping Extension education relevant for an increasingly digital and mobile audience 
 Mobile devices also increase the potential availability of Extension Professionals to clientele even when outside of the office or office hours, changing the way they work 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Community The Ed Tech Learning Network (EdTechLN) hosts webinars, TweetUps, blog and promotes professional development of Extension professionals in technology. Point of contact: Jamie Seger seger.23@osu.edu or JamieMSeger 
 Innovation Grants 
 
 Heidi Rader, University of Alaska. Her project created mobile app to conduct citizen agriculture research 
 Heather Wallace & Emily Tipton, University of Tennessee. \xe2\x80\x9c Instant access to Extension resources using augmented reality innovations \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Joey Puetz and Brian Clevely, University of Idaho. \xe2\x80\x9c Lighting the education fire with virtual environments \xe2\x80\x9d 
 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development and programming related to mobile learning. 
 
 Learn listings (webinars) tagged with \xe2\x80\x9capps\xe2\x80\x9d 
 Texas A&M maintains list of apps useful to Extension professionals 
 eXtension YouTube videos on \xe2\x80\x9cmobile apps\xe2\x80\x9d 
 Journal of Extension articles on mobile learning and mobile apps 
 EdTechLN list of podcasts offered by (and for) Extension professionals 
 
 Gaps 
 
 No courses on campus.extension.org were found that focused on mobile learning as it pertains to professional development in Extension. Courses for clientele that introduce or include mobile apps and resources were found. 
 
 Online Learning 
 How are Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through online learning? 
 
 Online learning is increasingly the preferred way for people to achieve formal as well as informal learning objectives 
 Online educational resources allow Extension professionals to enhance face to face educational programs in their local communities and extend the learning experience 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities The Network Literacy community focuses on the ability to use online technologies & social connections to effectively communicate, learn, work, & build communities of shared learning. 
 Innovation Grants 
 
 \xe2\x80\x9c Personalized Learning Experiences for Adult Learners \xe2\x80\x9d Gwyn Shelle and Ellen Darnell, Michigan State 
 \xe2\x80\x9c NeXT Talks: Igniting Innovation in Extending Knowledge \xe2\x80\x9d Holly Whitaker, Texas A&M 
 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered online, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 The campus.extension.org site showcases courses developed by (and for) Extension Professionals for online delivery, especially note the professional performance section. 
 Webinars \xe2\x80\x9c Establish Online Presence in Your Virtual Network \xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c Best Practices for Blazing Trail for Online Learners \xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c Strategy for Making Online Content Accessible \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Journal of Extension articles on online learning 
 Journal of Youth Development \xe2\x80\x9c Effective, efficient online training in Cooperative Extension \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Video- \xe2\x80\x9c Jane Hart – The Next Generation of Learning Practices \xe2\x80\x9d 
 
 Social Networks 
 How are Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through social networks? 
 
 Social networks are an effective mechanism to deepen local connections and to extend learning by seeking out conversations and resources that would otherwise be difficult to find 
 Social networks are also an information-gathering mechanism that can enhance local programs by connecting to more people, topics, resources, and conversations 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities 
 
 The Network Literacy community focuses on the ability to use online technologies & social connections to effectively communicate, learn, work, & build communities of shared learning. 
 The Ed Tech Learning Network (EdTechLN) hosts webinars, TweetUps, blog and promotes professional development of Extension professionals in technology. Point of contact: Jamie Seger seger.23@osu.edu or JamieMSeger 
 
 Innovation project The Virtual Communication Camp is training series to encourage participants to incorporate new and innovative technologies into their programming. 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Recorded webinars \xe2\x80\x9c DroneSinger. Social Media Experiment Lessons Learned \xe2\x80\x9d, \xe2\x80\x9c Social Networking: Boundaries and Professionalism \xe2\x80\x9d, and \xe2\x80\x9c Your Network Is Your Net Worth \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Journal of Extension articles on social networks 
 Network Smart Extension – UC Davis 
 Video – \xe2\x80\x9c NeXC 2014 – Master Panel \xe2\x80\x9d includes four well-respected experts on using social media, networks, and innovative technology in non-profit and educational settings 
 Video – \xe2\x80\x9c Automating Social Media \xe2\x80\x9d using IFTTT 
 TweetUps – EdTechLN hosts biweekly tweetups to connect Extension professionals 
 The Global Forum for Rural Advisory Services released two social media guides for Extension, one on policies and the other on social media shaping the future of service 
 The University of Maine developed guidelines/best practices for staff on social media 
 
 Time-to-Adoption Horizon: Two to Three Years\xc2\xa0(2018-2019) 
 3D Printing 
 How are Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through 3D printing? 
 
 3D printing provides opportunities for hands-on learning using specialized examples and may be useful in educational activities for youth, especially those involving STEM areas 
 Other common Extension programming areas are beginning to see applications of 3D printing – agriculture, entrepreneurship, and more 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 There were no eXtension communities, innovation grants, or fellowships identified as centering around 3D printing. 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating 3D printed materials, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Most existing resources or programs that mention 3D printing are part of youth (especially STEM) activities and Maker movement programs. 
 
 Gaps 
 There is significant lack of information readily available in this area. Some probably exists, but it will take additional effort to identify beyond what was done for this initial scan. 
 Big Data 
 How are Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through big data or how can access to resources that can process big data impact programming? 
 
 Trends and emerging issues that would benefit from updated, timely, research-based information such as that provided by Extension professionals can be identified using big data techniques and put Extension in proactive (vs reactive) mode 
 Programming by Extension professionals can help clientele become more aware of data that is collected about them, how to manage privacy, and also utilize their own data in making positive changes in their lives (precision ag, fitness, eating habits, etc.) 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities 
 
 The Big Data eXtension community shares resources on the concept of \xe2\x80\x98big data\xe2\x80\x99 within Extension and the Land Grant system. 
 Two specialized areas that are related to \xe2\x80\x98big data\xe2\x80\x99 for which eXtension communities exist are Citizen Science \xc2\xa0and the Internet of Things 
 
 Innovation projects Virginia Tech is leading the \xe2\x80\x9c eXtension Geo-Citizens Design Forest Farms \xe2\x80\x9d brings together programmers, geospatial experts, land management specialists, and citizen scientists. 
 Fellows 
 
 Katie Stofer, University of Florida is working on citizen science project on STEM. 
 eXtension will soon (Fall, 2016) fellowship in cooperation with GODAN on open research and data and links to Extension information. 
 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Webinar recordings. \xe2\x80\x9c Legal issues related to ag data \xe2\x80\x9d and \xe2\x80\x9c Economic issues related to big data in agriculture \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Online courses in campus.extension.org include \xe2\x80\x9c Precision Agriculture \xe2\x80\x9d, 
 Youtube playlist on \xe2\x80\x9c Big Data \xe2\x80\x9d (8 videos, accessed 9/19/16) 
 Journal of Extension articles on big data 
 
 Drones (Unmanned Arial Vehicles) 
 How are/could Extension Professionals impact their local communities through drones? 
 
 Unmanned aerial vehicles (drones) are increasingly being used in agriculture, disaster response, youth education, and more. Extension educators are uniquely poised to assist clientele in finding innovative uses for drones for their jobs and lifestyle, managing data and privacy, and conducting applied research with drones. 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities The Unmanned Aircraft Systems learning network in eXtension currently has nearly 100 members. 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Youtube channel. Victor Villegas, Oregon State. \xe2\x80\x9c Drone Singer \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Video playlist. eXtension Initiative \xe2\x80\x9c Drones \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Learn events (webinars) tagged with \xe2\x80\x9c drone \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Unmanned Aerial Systems in Agriculture website Twitter Facebook and Youtube 
 iThree Issue Corps projects – Youth Education Local Food Virtual Field Trips 
 4-H resource. National Youth Science Day (2016 focus is Drone Discovery) 
 
 Gaps 
 
 There were no online courses identified at campus.extension.org on drones or unmanned aerial systems (UAS) 
 There were no articles identified for the Journal of Extension on drones or UAS 
 
 Location Intelligence 
 How are/could Extension Professionals impact their local communities through geospatial technologies? 
 
 Location intelligence is affecting our clientele\xe2\x80\x99s lives in ways that range from consumer choices, parenting, job skills and professional performance, farm management, and creative expression. Educational programs in all of these areas need to provide awareness and skills on this topic so that youth, workers, families, and entrepreneurs can increase job skills, make informed choices, and prevent predatory practices. 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities 
 
 eXtension Map@Syst community focuses on how geospatial technologies make difference in people\xe2\x80\x99s lives. 
 Youth Geospatial Technology focuses on youth and 4-H programs 
 
 Innovation project Mapping for Storytelling & Engagement Shand Bradt, University of New Hampshire. The project hosted four webinars: 
 
 Using online maps to engage your audience \xe2\x80\x93 January 19, 2016 
 Making maps shine with ArcGIS Online \xe2\x80\x93 February 4, 2016 
 Share your story with maps \xe2\x80\x93 March 2, 2016 
 Create photo-based map in snap! \xe2\x80\x93 March 7, 2016 
 
 Innovation project. eXtension Geocitizens Design Forest Farms 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Map@Syst website http://www.exgeospatial.org/ Facebook Twitter Pinterest 
 University of New Hampshire Geospatial Training Center 
 Journal of Extension articles tagged \xe2\x80\x9c geospatial \xe2\x80\x9d 
 JOE. Online project mapping with researcher community input (2010) 
 4-H Geospatial curriculum materials 
 4-H National Youth Science Day (2013) focus was Maps and Apps 
 
 Time-to-Adoption Horizon: Four to Five Years\xc2\xa0(2020-2021) 
 Networked Objects/Internet of Things 
 How can Extension Professionals impact their local communities through the Internet of Things? 
 
 Smart devices are not only proliferating as ways to deliver educational programming but as subjects of programs. Extension educators will be able to reach and connect with clientele in new ways and provide programming on how to use data and information for making informed decisions in their daily life and at their jobs. 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities 
 
 Internet of Things (IoT) community focuses on wide range of topics connected to networked objects. 
 Wearable Technology learning network looks at interweaving technology into everyday life. They are also active on Google Plus Human Augmentation and Wearables 
 
 Fellow Jeff Hino, Oregon State recently completed fellowship with eXtension on the Internet of Things Jeff\xe2\x80\x99s fellowship final report is \xe2\x80\x9c The Internet of Things: Will Extension Be Ready? \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Video (Jeff Hino) The Internet of Things: Will Extension Be Ready? 
 Webinar What\xe2\x80\x99s this \xe2\x80\x9cThing\xe2\x80\x9d abou the \xe2\x80\x9cInternet of Things\xe2\x80\x9d? 
 iThree Issue Corps. Ergonomics and Wearables in Agriculture 
 University of Nebraska 4-H Wearable Technologies (WearTec) project 
 Blog. Seven reasons you should care about the Internet of Things 
 
 Gaps 
 There are not many webinars available on these topics or published case studies/articles about Extension programs that utilize networked objects. 
 Time-to-Adoption Horizon: Four to Five Years 
 Robotics 
 How can Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through robotics? 
 
 Robotics are growing STEM area for 4-H and youth programming. 
 Robotics and their applications to farm management will be programming topic for animal agriculture, agronomy, business management and have benefits when researching hazardous conditions for farm workers or emergency response. 
 Extension programming topics such as caregiving, entrepreneurship and community development, and health will all be impacted by robotic technology. 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Community The Youth Robotics community currently has 15 members (9/20/16) 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 4-H Robotics Resources including Junk Drawer Robotics curriculum 
 Online course. Texas 4-H Basics of Robotics 
 There is significant amount Journal of Extension articles tagged \xe2\x80\x9c robotics \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Many state Extension services have robotics program (usually part of the 4-H and youth programs). sample of those: Ohio State Alabama Texas and Maryland (Do search for your state name 4-H robotics to find if those exist in your state) 
 Pennsylvania State Extension includes robotic dairies in their Technology Tuesday webinar series including Collection and use of data in robotic milking systems Milk quality Cow behavior Facility design and Feed management (January 2017) 
 
 Gaps 
 More examples of resources, webinars, and publications for agriculture, health/wellness, and other topics beyond 4-H and youth development need to be located. 
 Time-to-Adoption Horizon: Four to Five Years 
 Telepresence 
 How will telepresence change programming and professional development for Extension Professionals? 
 
 The ability to deliver educational programs in multiple locations at the same time through telepresence offers the opportunity to efficiently deliver programs and interact with participants in conditions that mimic face-to-face programs 
 Hosting telepresence, clientele offers the opportunity to interact, answer questions, and provide solutions in ways similar to face to face office visits 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities The EdTechLN (Educational technology learning network) does not currently have resources on telepresence but contains the people and expertise to demonstrate and educate about this as the technology comes into greater use. 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 Michigan State University \xe2\x80\x9c New technology advances education in rural areas \xe2\x80\x9d 
 University of Wisconsin Extension hosts an annual distance learning conference In 2011, one paper was presented on \xe2\x80\x9c Using mobile telepresence in academia \xe2\x80\x9d 
 eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s Youtube channel includes quite few videos about Second Life (which is not the same as telepresence but related, immersive, \xe2\x80\x9cvirtual world\xe2\x80\x9d experience) 
 
 Gaps 
 Future innovation grants or fellowship opportunities may want to consider telepresence as focus area. 
 Time-to-Adoption Horizon: Four to Five Years 
 Wearable Technology 
 How are/could Extension Professionals impacting their local communities through wearable technology? How could wearable tech change extension programming and professional development? 
 
 Wearable technology offers the opportunity for clientele in many Extension program areas to make data-driven decisions that affect their daily lives, farms, health, and many other areas. Extension educators can be trusted resources in managing that data and utilizing it efficiently. 
 
 People, Programs & Activities 
 Communities Wearable Technology learning network looks at interweaving technology into everyday life. They are also active on Google Plus Human Augmentation and Wearables 
 Resources 
 Publications, webinars, videos, and other resources for professional development, creating learning resources delivered via mobile device, and connecting with other Extension professionals. 
 
 wearable tech survey was conducted. (Jill is working on finding out if results were published anywhere) 
 JOE article on program for overweight teens utilizing wearables 
 iThree Issue Corps. Ergonomics and Wearables in Agriculture 
 University of Nebraska 4-H Wearable Technologies (WearTec) project 
 
 Gaps 
 Webinars and other professional development resources on wearables are not widely available at national level.

							 Impact Collaborative 

						 
						 
							 The eXtension Foundation \xe2\x80\x9cImpact Collaborative” is an accelerator for\xc2\xa0Cooperative Extension professionals to amplify their impact on local\xc2\xa0issues. This investment has built the only national network in the Land Grant University System that uses proven process to accelerate capacity for projects with problem-solving teams so that significant local change happens. See the Impact Collaborative story. 
 
 In 2017-2018, the eXtension Foundation with the Cooperative Extension System (CES) is planning to bring together nearly 2,000 CES professionals and their community partners into multi-themed Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0experiences to develop and strengthen local impact in behavioral health, food systems, diversity & inclusion, and regionally-focused themes to be determined with partners. Our goal is to work with 15-35 Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0members at each eXtension Foundation member institution in 2017-2018. 
 Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0Background 
 Since early \xc2\xa02016 eXtension\xc2\xa0has successfully engaged hundreds of \xc2\xa0Cooperative Extension professionals in the development of impactful projects addressing topics such as local food systems, climate, small business development, enhancing rural capacity, equine biosecurity, financial management, backyard poultry, women in agriculture and diversity and inclusion. These efforts were part of the eXtension Issue Corps program. \xc2\xa0In 2017, the eXtension Foundation rebranded the Issue Corps as the Impact Collaborative 
 The Impact Collaborative members reported working differently as result, including: 
 
 93% believed the Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0participation was positive experience. 
 86% gained awareness of, access to, or training in the use of new tools. 
 83% were exposed to new or different ideas and/or viewpoints. 
 82% interacted with other Extension professionals outside their normal professional circle 
 68% feel they can influence either their institution and/or their professional field in new ways after participating in the Impact Collaborative. 
 The majority reported improved ability to participate in professional discussions, developed confidence in sharing resources, gained comfort in recommending alternate approaches to ideas, and are working differently because of their Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0participation 
 
 The Impact Collaborative Process 
 The Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0is constructed around four essential elements: Design thinking, key informant\xc2\xa0expertise, growing base of evidence-based practice and dynamic synergy that happens\xc2\xa0when colleagues passionate about solving the same issues network face-to-face and online. 
 
 Access to Key Informants 
 Key Informant is recognized expert from either land-grant university, non-profit organization, or private industry, willing to share the latest research and innovations in Extension and related practice to help Collaborative members accelerate their project impact and scale. Key Informants include our cadre of eXtension Fellows funded in partnership with organizations such as USDA-NIFA, Global Open Data for Agriculture and Nutrition (GODAN), Digital Green and organizations of the Joint Council for Extension Professionals (JCEP). Locally-identified and willing Key Informants are also critical part of the Impact Collaborative process. 
 Design Thinking 
 
 The catalyzing event in the Impact Collaborative process is face-to-face Designathon. This 1.5-day event is focused on critically examining the structure of each project including: understanding local needs; identifying research and existing evidence-based programs and practices to meet that need, concept mapping the project’s attributes and elements; and identifying gaps and opportunities for greater impact and greater scale. This work is done in consultation with Key Informants to incorporate the latest relevant research and innovations. The Designathon aids Collaborative\xc2\xa0members and their projects by providing education and skill building tailored to specific needs, leveraging resources by networking and forming partnerships, and leveraging innovative approaches and processes to generate new resources needed to fulfill project goals. \xc2\xa0 
 Dynamic Networking Synergy 
 While there are myriad conferences that focus on professional development, an eXtension Designathon takes action toward creating greater measurable, visible local impact by local community Extension educators and agents. Designing project as part of the Impact Collaborative\xc2\xa0empowers, advances, and accelerates results. Bringing like minds together to network creates synergy of creativity, innovation, and success. Collaborative\xc2\xa0alumni attest to enhanced project outcomes, the creation of new social and professional networks, and dynamic relationships that create systemic change in how Cooperative Extension professionals address local problems. 
 Growing Evidence Base 
 The Impact Collaborative experience is designed to foster the evidence of local impact and to document solutions that work in way that can be shared across the Extension system. Throughout the process, eXtension provides access to Key Informants and other critical eXtension tools and resources while projects move from preparation to implementation to impact. As we begin to learn from our first cohorts in 2016…results happen! Stories about Impact Collaborative projects are found on the eXtension website here
