							 2016 eXtension Fellows 

						 
						 
							 eXtension Names Four eXtension Fellows and the First eXtension/GODAN Fellow for 2016 
 The eXtension Foundation proudly introduces the four new Fellows in its seventh annual eXtension Fellowship program and the first new eXtension/GODAN Fellow eXtension Fellows come from eXtension Foundation Premium Member Institutions and spend one year advancing knowledge on applied innovation in their topic area for the benefit of all Cooperative Extension professionals. 
 The 2016 topic areas focus on new approaches to Makers, Social Media, and Big Data. Following are the 2016 eXtension Foundation Fellows, their projects, and the focus of their plans. 
 Seventh Annual eXtension Fellows 
 Dave Francis, Extension Associate Professor, Utah State University 
 \xe2\x80\x9c Maker Movement, Horticulture Fusion \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Within the Maker Movement, there is new trend developing with tie to agriculture and gardening. Known as \xe2\x80\x9cgeek gardening,\xe2\x80\x9d it refers to gardening enhanced with technology-focused methods to increase the production of plant products or to solve issues such as irrigation or pest control. Geek gardening is of particularly attractive to gardening enthusiasts interested in local, small-scale agriculture and growing in small urban environments. related interest among these makers is \xe2\x80\x9cslow tools\xe2\x80\x9d–appropriately scaled, lightweight, affordable and open-source tools for small-scale farmers. The focus of Dave\xe2\x80\x99s work will be to identify and showcase variety of innovators, projects and solutions in the geek gardening arena and, using eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s outreach technologies, to introduce their innovations to gardening enthusiasts and small-acreage producers–and also to tech enthusiasts to encourage them to turn their hand to horticulture topics. Project Page 
 Daphne Richards, County Agent and Educator, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service 
 \xe2\x80\x9cExpediting Social Media Campaign Management with Evergreen Content Development and Distribution\xe2\x80\x9d 
 By now, most Cooperative Extension professionals have tried one or more social media platforms to promote programs or share educational content. Many have also created videos, infographics, webinars, and more. Each project is surprisingly time-consuming, requiring strategic planning, content development, project management, posting and curating. What is mounting up in Extension is good deal of duplication of offerings on both emerging issues and timeless topics that could be addressed with single video or infographic designed to be \xe2\x80\x9cevergreen\xe2\x80\x9d and applicable to broad geographic area. Daphne\xe2\x80\x99s project is to investigate topics ripe for creation from an \xe2\x80\x9cevergreen-content\xe2\x80\x9d perspective and create top-tips, how-to videos, seasonal advice and more to share with peers locally and, where applicable, regionally and nationally. \xc2\xa0She will also evaluate social media sharing platforms to help individuals and teams manage their posting of evergreen content via social media. 
 Christian Schmieder, Qualitative Research Specialist and Lecturer, University of Wisconsin Cooperative Extension (Program Development and Evaluation Unit) 
 \xe2\x80\x9c Responding to the \xe2\x80\x98Data Imperative\xe2\x80\x99 in Extension:\xc2\xa0 Developing National Online Qualitative Analysis and Analysis Software Learning Platform \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Big Data is big challenge for Cooperative Extension and its partner organizations. Increasingly Extension is expected to produce strong, data-driven insights for variety of audiences from ever larger, more diverse and complex data sources. How are Extension institutions and professionals to build the capacity to analyze large to massive amounts of qualitative data on the national, regional, state and team level? At all four levels, large qualitative datasets exist in such forms as impact statements, annual reports, research reports, results narratives, and more. The challenge is not collecting the data, but analyzing it in consistent, methodologically and procedurally sound way that facilitates using it. Christian plans to assess the scalability of analysis-focused software training required to build proficiency among Extension professionals in using Qualitative Data Analysis Software to analyze large qualitative data sets. Building on the model developed in his unit at his home institution, University of Wisconsin, he proposes to develop working prototype for this training, including online materials and teaching modules that might be disseminated for national use. Project Page 
 Laura Thompson, University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Extension Educator, Cropping Systems and Agriculture Technologies 
 \xe2\x80\x9c Data Visualization in Publications, Live Presentations, and Recorded Data Videos \xe2\x80\x9d 
 The world of Big Data is exploding with our increasing ability to generate and collect data in all the sectors Cooperative Extension serves. In addition to the challenge of how to store and process this data, equally important is how to make it meaningful for Extension\xe2\x80\x99s many audiences. In short, how can data be distilled and presented so that the intended audience can interpret it, remember it, and apply it to change behavior. Data visualization tools are now available so most Extension professionals can develop the capacity to collect and process large quantities of data to produce effective charts, figures and graphics for their various audiences. Data visualization is an important skill to expand in Extension\xe2\x80\x99s toolset. Laura will focus on data visualization and presentation for written publications, oral presentations and recorded presentations and develop best practices, drawn from examples at her home institution, University of Nebraska, for dissemination throughout Extension through eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s technologies and professional development outreach capabilities. Project Page 
 First eXtension/GODAN Fellow 
 Justin G. Smith, Ph.D., Director, Mason County Extension and Assistant Professor, Community Economic Development, Washington State University 
 \xe2\x80\x9c Unified Knowledge Translation Framework for Integrating Interdisciplinary Research and Scholarly Activity Related to Climate Resilience and Food Security. \xe2\x80\x9d 
 For Cooperative Extension, growing Big Data challenge is the need to address issues supported by collective ability to organize, link, retrieve and translate cross-disciplinary data, research and action. Addressing this need requires that Extension begins the work NOW on shaping the next-generation information architecture for Extension professionals, partners, and the broader communities related to Extension work. Working with eXtension and GODAN leadership, Justin plans to develop prototype \xe2\x80\x9cUnified Knowledge Translation Framework\xe2\x80\x9d that will demonstrate model for integrating interdisciplinary research and scholarly activity related specifically to climate resilience and food security. By leveraging innovations in cognitive computing, open data, artificial/collective intelligence and more, he plans to develop general structure and formal technical specifications to inform designing semi-autonomous (self-labelling, self-organizing) metadata labeling and indexing/search API for Extension and GODAN partners. This work is first step toward developing metadata-labeling protocol and production-level indexing system that can organize and link relevant information from diverse domains of knowledge, institutions, and other sources for ultimate use by Cooperative Extension and its partners 
 About the eXtension Fellowships Programs 
 The eXtension Fellowship program is offered in partnership with USDA-NIFA and dedicated to developing projects on applied innovation in U.S. Cooperative Extension settings. The eXtension/GODAN Fellowship is offered through partnership with Global Open Data for Agriculture and Nutrition (GODAN) and it focuses on testing and demonstrating protocols, including the use of competency frameworks, to make eXtension and Extension information more open, accessible and linked to open research and data. 
 For more information on the Fellows or eXtension Fellowship programs,please contact Jerry Thomas, Director of eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s Innovation Lab

 Knowledge Base 
 				 
			 
		 
	 
		 
							 
					 

 



						 
							 Innovation 

						 
						 
							 At eXtension, we define innovation as creativity applied to produce positive impacts. The purpose of eXtension and its projects, teams, and futuring research is to help Cooperative Extension professionals make visible and measurable impacts by identifying, incubating, lifting up and fostering innovation to accelerate the adoption of innovation. 
 The goal is to provide safe, structured venues for \xe2\x80\x9cexperimenters\xe2\x80\x9d to create and test new ideas. eXtension provides structure for them to share and to identify intersections among their efforts and ideas that suggest further opportunities. In short, we operate as dynamic liquid network that facilitates both focus and agility for participating experimenters. 
 Fellowships and Innovation Grant Projects 
 eXtension funds fellowships and innovation grant projects as part of our effort to identify and incubate innovation in the Cooperative Extension System. Recent fellowships have included topics such as knowledge networks, large-scale qualitative data analysis, citizen science, the Maker movement and much more. Learn more about the 2015 Fellows and the 2016 Fellows 
 Innovation grants have been awarded to develop programs around topics like story mapping, smart beehives, 4-H Maker festivals, Bio-band fitness trackers for youth, drones for small farms, and others. Learn more about the 2016 innovation projects and the 2017 innovation projects 
 Each initiative operates with contract that specifies the structure, timelines, goals, outputs, and intended impact. participants receive mentoring in defining the research, prototype development, adoption plans and other steps of the innovation process. Outputs might include presentations, demonstrations, reports, published papers, webinars, blog posts and other communications key to sharing ideas and advancing adoption. 
 Connecting Extension Professionals and Innovation 
 Helping Extension professionals work differently is one of the main goals of eXtension. The flagship program for this is the Impact Collaborative. This program seeks to help Extension professionals increase their visibility and measurable local impact. Learn more about the Impact Collaborative… 
 The Ed Tech Learning Network is vehicle for connecting innovation-minded Extension professionals and empowering them to put technology to use in their programs. The EdTechLN hosts regular tweetups and offers weekly newsletter. The founders of the EdTechLN recently received the 2017 JCEP Award for Creative Excellence To date, 267 people have joined the network and 315 follow on Facebook. 
 eXtension also sponsored the development of the New Media Consortium Horizon Report 2016-2021: Cooperative Extension Edition The report was compiled by 50-person expert panel. It will guide many of the future initiatives of eXtension with the goal of increasing the visible and measurable local impact of Extension professionals. 
 Innovate events have been held in Oregon, Utah, and Ohio in 2017 with another to be held in Delaware. These events bring together Extension faculty and staff to focus on the creative process and empower them to work differently. The innovate events were pilot programs from which the lessons learned and feedback are being used to shape the Impact Collaborative process. 
 
 Get Involved 
 Be sure to watch for the call for proposals for the next Impact Collaborative (expected September 2017). Anyone at an eXtension member institution is eligible to apply. The call will be distributed to eXtension ID holders via email. Future Fellows and innovation grant will be selected from Impact Collaborative alumni. 
 Join the EdTechLN to receive announcements about tweetups and the weekly newsletter. 
 For more information about any of these programs, contact Jamie Seger jamieseger@extension.org or Paul Hill paul.hill@usu.edu ).

							 Integrating Drones and Precision Agriculture with Beef Production 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
 Integrating small unmanned aerial systems and precision agriculture with beef production systems 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Virginia Tech 
 
 
 Location: 
Blacksburg, VA, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 John McGee 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 Key Words 
 Unmanned Aerial Systems 
Precision Agriculture 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 The goal of this project is to introduce innovative technology that can be adopted by Extension, local producers, and other stakeholders to support increased efficiencies in ag operations, especially beef cattle production. The small unmanned aerial systems (sUAS) regulatory landscape changed dramatically with the FAA\xe2\x80\x99s revisions that took place over the summer, 2016. As result of these regulatory changes, Virginia Cooperative Extension (VCE) has been developing in-house expertise to support sUAS applications across program areas to support an array of needs by managers and producers. Precision agriculture is one of these potential application areas. 
 Based on findings from this project, VCE agents and specialists, as well as other stakeholders, will better understand some of the limitations, challenges, and benefits associated with the use of sUAS to support agricultural management. Using this information, we will be able to refine future programming efforts that can be used to support agricultural producers not only across the state but in other regions of the U.S. and beyond. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 We traveled to the Southwest Virginia Agricultural Research and Extension Center and presented at their annual Forage Field Expo. We had great turnout with over 100 livestock producers. We held ‘drone overview’ presentation, Q&A session, poster presentation, and couple of small unmanned aerial systems (sUAS) demonstrations. Based on feedback from our sUAS presentations this summer, producers do have an interest about sUAS and how/if this technology can support their needs. There is significant amount of interest in the potential of sUAS by cattle producers and by organizations that are supporting cattle producers. We are selecting producers for our pilot programs [August 2017]. 
 Also of note, we have received some seed funding to develop short sUAS online tutorials. These tutorials can be used as online training resources for individuals who are studying for the FAA’s Remote Pilot Knowledge Test (AKA FAA Part 107 Exam).

							 Evolution of the Impact Collaborative 

						 
						 
							 The Impact Collaborative started in 2016 as the Issue Corps program. The first three cohorts of the Issue Corps program are described below. The procedures and the lessons learned from these evolved into the Impact Collaborative. 
 View all Issue Corps projects by region or state… 
 The eXtension\xc2\xa0Issue Corps 
 Increasing Extension professionals\xe2\x80\x99 effectiveness in addressing issues of importance to local, state and national audiences is the mission of the Issue Corps. Issue Corps members, selected from eXtension Foundation member institutions combine their talent, \xe2\x80\x9con-the-ground\xe2\x80\x9d knowledge, and energy to serve as volunteer innovators who participate in creating next-generation Cooperative Extension System tools for achieving increased impact. 
 Climate and Food Systems 2016 Issue Corps 
 In 2016, the first cohort of the Issue Corps focused on the issues of climate and food systems The members of this cohort represent Extension professionals who were already working on issues related to climate and food systems. They self-identified as having strong desire to work \xe2\x80\x9chands-on\xe2\x80\x9d to create new methods for addressing critical issues.\xc2\xa0126 corps members representing 70 projects were selected. Read about some of the successes of the Issue Corps… 
 Community Issue Corps 2016 
 The second Issue Corps cohort focused on communities affiliated with eXtension, the Community Issue Corps Eight projects with 27 members participated in Designathon to develop concept maps and interact with key informants to refine their program plan. 
 Diversity and Inclusion Issue Corps 2017 
 The third cohort of the Issue Corps is focused on diversity and inclusion and includes 39 projects with over 80 team members participating in Designathon and series of professional development activities. Twenty-one key informants are mentoring the Corps in their project plans. Learn more about the Designathon experience… 
 
 Future Plans for the Issue Corps 
 All Issue Corps members receive special opportunities for professional growth, including support, resources, and attendance at special eXtension events where they receive ongoing training and experience in designing and implementing innovation strategies. 
 Cooperative Extension System professionals have long, proud history of serving as catalysts for putting research-based knowledge from land-grant universities on wide range of topics into action in rural and urban communities nationwide. The Issue Corps is working \xe2\x80\x9chands-on\xe2\x80\x9d to create and apply new methods for addressing the critical issues facing their communities.

							 Jeff Hino 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Jeff Hino 
 eXtension Internet of Things Fellow 
 Jeff is the learning technology leader at Oregon State University working in Extension & Experiment Station Communications. He facilitates adoption of new communication and learning technologies and the OSU Ask an Expert initiative. He sees his role as one that empathizes with and encourages people as they begin or continue their relationship with technology. Jeff has an extensive background in instructional design, technology, and media production. He is also member of the eXtension Educational Technology Learning Network. Jeff was the 2015 eXtension Fellow exploring the Internet of Things.

							 Jeff Piestrak 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Jeff Piestrak, Cornell University 
 \xe2\x80\x9cOptimizing for Health: Linking & Leveraging Land Grant Knowledge Assets in Support of Healthy People, Food Systems & Communities” 
 Serving for many years as an Outreach & Engagement Specialist at Cornell\xe2\x80\x99s Mann Library, Jeff Piestrak has recently focused his attentions on digital tools and resources supporting Cornell\xe2\x80\x99s research, learning, and outreach mission, including the creation of networked knowledge commons and \xe2\x80\x9cpublic knowledge spaces\xe2\x80\x9d. He also works with variety of food systems groups and initiatives, including the eXtension Community, Local and Regional Food Systems CoP 
 Jeff’s fellowship focused on digital assets (data and information), and systems for managing and sharing those within the context of community and regional food systems efforts. He is particularly interested in how we can move beyond simple dissemination models/designs of these systems (during an era when we are increasingly \xe2\x80\x9cdisintermediated\xe2\x80\x9d), toward ones that are better suited to social knowledge creation processes. What we\xe2\x80\x99re finding is that often wicked problems like hunger cannot be solved by treating them solely as technical \xe2\x80\x9cknowledge deficit\xe2\x80\x9d problem \xe2\x80\x93we must also acknowledge the social dimensions. Not doing so can actually make things worse. Simply providing expert information will not work.

 Ithaca, NY, USA

							 Justin Smith 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Justin Smith, Washington State University 
 \xe2\x80\x9c Unified Knowledge Translation Framework for Integrating Interdisciplinary Research and Scholarly Activity Related to Climate Resilience and Food Security \xe2\x80\x9d 
 Justin G. Smith, PhD. is the Director of Mason County Extension and Assistant Professor, Community Economic Development, Washington State University. He is the first eXtension/GODAN Fellow. 
 This fellowship is in special area of interest. Its purpose is to demonstrate methods for linking research and Extension information in support of learning and innovation. The Fellow, through participation in the GODAN network, will test and demonstrate protocols, including the use of competency frameworks, making eXtension and Extension information more open, accessible and linked to open research and data. 
 Increasingly, Cooperative Extension and its partner organizations are expected to produce strong, data-driven insights for variety of audiences from Big Qualitative Data\xe2\x80\x93ever larger, more diverse and complex data sources. To meet this need, Extension needs to build capacity to analyze large amounts of qualitative data in consistent, methodologically sound way. Christian will assess the scalability of analysis-focused Qualitative Data Analysis Software training and develop working prototype for Extension, including online materials and teaching modules that might be disseminated for national use.

							 Katie Stofer 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Katie Stofer 
 eXtension Citizen Science Fellow 
Katie is research assistant professor at the University of Florida in the Agricultural Education and Communication department. Her research focuses on Science, Technology, Engineering, and Math (STEM), especially in free-choice or informal education and outreach settings. She\xe2\x80\x99s interested in how the public gathers, makes meaning from, and uses current scientific research findings and how that use relates to their science identities.

							 Laura Thompson 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Laura Thompson 2016 eXtension Fellow 
 
 \xe2\x80\x9cData Visualization in Publications, Live Presentations, and Recorded Data Videos\xe2\x80\x9d 
 Laura is\xc2\xa0a cropping systems – ag technologies extension educator based in Lincoln. She co-coordinates the Nebraska On-Farm Research Network (NOFRN) \xc2\xa0which helps farmers answer crop production questions using customized on-farm\xc2\xa0research. 
 Laura’s fellowship efforts will focus on data visualization and presentation for written publications, oral presentations and recorded presentations and develop best practices, drawn from examples at her home institution, University of Nebraska, for dissemination throughout Extension through eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s technologies and professional development outreach capabilities.

							 Leadership Team 

						 
						 
							 Leadership Team 
 CEO, Christine Geith, Ph.D. – christinegeith@extension.org 
COO, Beverly Coberly – beverlycoberly@extension.org 
 CFO, Peter Aamodt – peteraamodt@extension.org 
Director, Issue Response, Terry Meisenbach – terry.meisenbach@extension.org 
Director, National Presence, Larry Lippke Ph.D. – llippke@extension.org 
 eXtension CEO 
 Dr. Christine Geith is CEO to the eXtension Foundation, serving the U.S. Cooperative Extension System with digital strategies for more visible and measurable public impact. 
 The former assistant provost and executive director of MSU Global at Michigan State University, Dr. Geith brings 25 years of leadership experience creating entrepreneurial, technology-based ventures at both technical regional university, Rochester Institute of Technology, and top-ranked land-grant university, Michigan State University. She provides leadership for innovative digital strategies for programs, research, Extension, outreach and corporate engagement. She has worked with new organizations and served on number of boards, pioneering new business models and technologies to generate significant value for clients and stakeholders. 
 Dr. Geith holds Ph.D. in Curriculum, Instruction and Administration from the University of Nebraska, Lincoln; an MBA from Rochester Institute of Technology and B.S. in Design from State University College at Buffalo. 
 Follow her on Twitter @christinegeith view her professional background on LinkedIn or view her SlideShare page 
 eXtension COO 
 Dr. Beverly Coberly was appointed as eXtension COO in September 2016. Beverly has held steady progression of administrative leadership roles in University of Missouri Extension, culminating most recently in the position of Associate Vice-Provost and Associate Director. In this position she has been responsible for leadership of statewide programming as well as associated budgeting, staffing, reporting and leadership development of employees. 
 Throughout her more than 35-year career with Missouri Extension, she has worked at nearly every level of Extension operations\xe2\x80\x93region, state and county; on-campus and off-campus; legislators, funders and other internal and external resource partners. She has provided leadership and administrative liaison to many initiatives at all these levels while also managing number of employees. Beverly holds Bachelor of Science from the College of the Ozarks, Master of Science from University of Missouri-Columbia and recently completed PhD in Architectural Studies, Human Environmental Sciences, at the University of Missouri-Columbia. 
 eXtension CFO 
 Peter Aamodt was appointed eXtension CFO in January, 2016. Peter has served in wide range of financial and business officer roles in his career. \xc2\xa0He has worked in both large and small organizations and is very experienced at balancing broad strategic focus with hands-on governance activities. 
 Most recently he served as Interim Director, Strategic Procurement and Contracting, at Wright State University in Dayton, Ohio, and prior to that was Vice President, Finance, at Thomas More College in Crestview Hills, Kentucky. His work history also includes progression of increasing financial responsibilities in the University of Tennessee system.

							 Lighting the Education Fire with Virtual Environments 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
Lighting the Education Fire with Virtual Environments and Oculus Rift Technology 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 University of Idaho 
 
 
 Location: 
Moscow, ID, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Joey Peutz 
 
 
 
 Brian Cleveley 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 This project proposes to extend Cooperative Extensions\xe2\x80\x99 outreach via 24/7 public experiential learning tools using the Oculus Rift virtual reality headset, web browser-based virtual environment (single and multi-user) and an app accessed through mobile devices supporting 3D virtual worlds. The primary demonstration project is simulation to learn about home safety when threatened by wildfire. The project offers the opportunity to experience wildfire safety experience as an immersive 3D simulation with participants customizing the experience variables. The ability to access the same simulation content across three different platforms is also new way of delivering knowledge making it more flexible and adaptable to meet the changing needs of Extension and their constituents. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 The Blaze computer simulation is now available at\xc2\xa0 securetheshelter.com Blaze is stand-alone wildfire preparedness computer simulation designed to educate participants about the wildfire risks of their home and community and what steps to take to reduce the risks of ignition. 
 
 
 
 
 Related Links: 
 Project Page – Users can learn more about the Blaze project and download files to experience Blaze using: 
 
 Oculus Rift (Windows based) 
 WebGL (run from browser) 
 Standalone: Windows and Macintosh 
 Android Mobile (tablet or phone) 
 Google Cardboard (Android based)

 eXtension Makers Fellow 
 Paul is an Extension Associate Professor in Washington County, Utah. His areas of expertise are: youth leadership, STEM education, volunteerism, social media, and small business development. Paul is the leader of the eXtension Maker Network and Community Strategy Leader for the national Educational Technology Learning Network.

							 eXtension Foundation Institutional Membership 

						 
						 
							 eXtension Foundation is non-profit, member-based organization. Members are Cooperative Extension Services at land-grant institutions across the United States. Membership is offered in two categories: premium and basic. 
 All Extension professionals, whether their institution is member or non-member, can access eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s resources, benefits and communities. Benefits for individual Extension professionals vary based on their institution\xe2\x80\x99s membership. 
 For complete information please download the Membership Handbook: 
 Download the 2015 Membership Handbook (PDF)

							 National Extension Web-mapping Tool 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
 National Extension Web-mapping Tool (NEWT) 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 University of New Hampshire 
 
 
 Location: 
Durham, NH, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Shane Bradt 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 Key Words 
 Geospatial Technology 
 Story Mapping 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 The goal of the National Extension Web-mapping Tool (NEWT), created during previous eXtension Innovation grant is to increase the effective use of spatial data to make strategic decisions regarding planning and programming in the Cooperative Extension System (CES). NEWT is not simply way to add data layers to map, but instead is straightforward online tool for exploring spatial data relevant to CES in the ways which CES staff and administrators find useful, including maps, tables, and graphs. 
 Once NEWT is released publicly in late spring 2017, this Innovation Grant will focus on promoting NEWT throughout CES, offering professional development on the use of NEWT, and gathering feedback regarding the current version, including ideas regarding new functions and datasets which could further broaden the use of NEWT. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 The beta of the tool is about to be released (July 2017). Sign up to receive an invitation to test the tool

							 NeXT Talks: Igniting Innovation in Extending Knowledge 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
NeXT Talks: Igniting Innovation in Extending Knowledge 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Texas A&M AgriLife Extension 
 
 
 Location: 
College Station, TX, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Holly Whitaker 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
This project expands platform designed to inspire innovation in Cooperative Extension program delivery by quickly connecting educators to material on emerging topics. These \xe2\x80\x9ctalks\xe2\x80\x9d are timely, proactive, interactive and position educators nationwide with information to position them as front line resources in their communities. Using streaming video and social media, NeXT Talks allow audience members to engage with subject matter specialists within and outside the land grant system.

							 Personalized Learning Experiences for Adult Learners 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
Building Personalized Learning Experiences for Adult Learners through Adaptive Learning Techniques 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Michigan State University 
 
 
 Location: 
East Lansing, MI, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Gwyn Shelle 
 Role: Project Leader 
 heyboerg@anr.msu.edu 
 
 
 Ellen Darnell 
Dawn Earnesty 
Allen Pilkenton 
Erin Powell 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
 Adaptive learning models demonstrate the ability to build personalized learning paths for users based on data and analytics. It is model suggesting that learners will engage with content in different ways. For example, some participants bring with them prior knowledge and would prefer to focus on the content they need to know rather than follow linear learning process. 
 This goal of this project is to evaluate and pilot adaptive learning tools for future cooperative extension programming. The team of experts is researching several existing adaptive learning tools and consulting with experts in the field of online learning who are currently implementing adaptive learning into their programming. 
 Specific objectives for this project include: 
 
 
 Increasing knowledge of adaptive learning tools through research and collaboration with experts. Adaptive learning tools will be assessed and ranked based on potential use within CES programming. 
 
 
 Designing and delivering adaptive learning activities within existing online courses through several selected pilot projects. 
 
 
 Evaluating the effectiveness of the adaptive learning experiences. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 significant contribution of this project was the ability to test new way of teaching online. Adaptive learning is an emerging concept in the field of online learning and especially new within CES programming. Through our work, we focused on testing adaptive learning experiences with several different tools. No matter what tool was selected it was important to have content, activities, and assessments which had strong ties to sound learning objectives. Based on this, Learning Objective Outline was created to aid in the development of an online course. This template is useful to an individual or team that is building an online course as it requires the user to associate all content within course to learning objective. To download this template for your own use go to Learning Objective Outline/Storyboard 
 Through our pilot courses, we built adaptive activities and courses. The adaptive activities were created using Articulate Storyline. These activities were built to reinforce concepts within an online course. An example was created in the topic area of equine behavior: Adaptive Learning – Articulate/Storyline Example In this activity, users are guided along learning path based on their knowledge which is tested through series of assessments. To download the Articulate Storyline file go to Adaptive Articulate Storyline Template In another pilot we tested an adaptive platform, D2L LeaP, which presented participants in course with custom learning path based on pre-assessment. \xc2\xa0We asked participants to compare past learning experiences to the same content presented in an adaptive manner. Eighty participants completed the pilot. Results indicated 77% agreed/strongly agreed the adaptive format was helpful in mastering content. Furthermore, 96% would take more adaptive courses. 
 selected comment: 
 
 \xe2\x80\x9cI really appreciate being part of this experiment. enjoyed the content-particularly the links to the more in-depth lectures. would recommend it highly.\xe2\x80\x9d 
 
 
 
 
 
 Recent Publications: 
 
 
 Shelle, GA., Powell, E., Darnall, E., Pilkenton, A., Earnesty, D. (2016). Building Personalized Learning Experiences through Adaptive Learning Techniques Online Learning Consortium Accelerate Conference, Orlando, FL, November 17, 2016. 
 PowerPoint Presentation: Building Personalized Learning Experiences through Adaptive Learning Techniques 
 Learning Objective Template: Learning Objective Based Storyboard 
 Articulate Storyline Template: Adaptive Learning – Articulate/Storyline (Note: Users must have Articulate Storyline in order to view the file.)

							 eXtension Privacy Policy 

						 
						 
							 (Updated February 2017) 
 Your privacy is important to eXtension Foundation (\xe2\x80\x9c eXtension \xe2\x80\x9d). This privacy policy (\xe2\x80\x9c Privacy Policy \xe2\x80\x9d) provides you with information regarding the personal information collected during your visits to the eXtension website (the \xe2\x80\x9c Site \xe2\x80\x9d), how it is used, with whom it may be shared and what choices you have regarding collection and distribution of your personal information. 
 eXtension reserves the right, at any time, to modify this Privacy Policy. If eXtension makes revisions that change the way we collect, use, or share personal information, we will post those changes in this Privacy Policy. You should review this Privacy Policy periodically so that you keep up to date on our most current policies and practices. We will note the effective date of the latest version of our Privacy Policy at the beginning of this Privacy Policy. 
 What personal information may be collected? 
 eXtension collects personal information when users voluntarily submit it to us.\xc2\xa0 For example, when you register with eXtension, we collect personal information, including your name and address. We may also ask for information about your areas of interest to provide relevant resources to better serve your needs. You may choose not to share your geographical information or areas of interest, but we encourage you to do so to receive more personalized experience with eXtension. 
 Unregistered users of eXtension must provide their e-mail address and name when providing comment or asking question. 
 How will my information be used? 
 Information provided by unregistered users may be used to follow-up on the particular question or comment from the user. Users have the option to register or opt-in to receive additional information or communications from eXtension. 
 For registered users, information collected during registration may be used to provide tailored information and resources for each user based on areas of interest and geographical location. Geographical information may be used to provide customized home page featuring relevant local information and news. Information collected on your areas of interest may be used to provide you with publications and news related to your interests on your personalized home page. Registered users have the option to allow eXtension to share your personal information with local Extension offices to better serve your needs. You may also choose to receive local Extension newsletters and other communications. To ensure your privacy, you will be provided with way to unsubscribe from any newsletters you may receive. 
 Information sharing and disclosure 
 We do not share or sell your personal information to third parties except as described in this Privacy Policy. Registered users will have the choice to opt-out of any sharing of personal information with our partner universities or local eXtension offices. eXtension may share your personal information with service providers that perform services for eXtension, such as providing marketing assistance and analyzing data. For example, we use cookies at extension.org from service providers such as Google Analytics to collect user traffic data. There may also be instances when eXtension may disclose your personal information without providing you with choice in order to protect the legal rights of eXtension, our partner universities or local eXtension offices, agents, and employees; to honor request that you have made through the Site; to protect the safety and security of other users; to protect against fraud or for risk management purposes; or to comply with the law or legal process. 
 While browsing the eXtension Site, you may sometimes encounter links to other companies or agencies that are not controlled by eXtension or its partners. Please be aware that eXtension is not responsible for the privacy practices of such other sites. We encourage you to be cautious when leaving the eXtension Site and carefully read the privacy statements of other websites. 
 If you make comment, use bulletin board or chat room on the eXtension Site, you should be aware that any personal information you submit there can be read, collected, or used by other users of these forums, and could be used to send you unsolicited messages. We are not responsible for the personal information you choose to submit in these forums. 
 Access to personal information 
 If your personal information changes, or if you no longer want to be part of the eXtension Site, you may correct, update, or deactivate it by making the change on your account information page or by emailing eXtension at privacy@extension.org 
 Choice/Opt-Out 
 You may use the eXtension Site without registering. Some features require you to input your name and e-mail address in order to receive follow-up from eXtension. When you register to use the eXtension Site, you will be asked to share personal information that will allow you to receive personalized experience on the Site. You may choose not to share information other than your name and e-mail address. We provide you the opportunity to “opt-out” of having your personal information used for certain purposes, including sharing your information with local Extension offices or tailoring your experience based on your geolocation, when we ask for this information. 
 If you choose to receive local newsletters or other communications and later decide you no longer wish to subscribe, you may opt out of receiving them by following the unsubscribe instructions included in each newsletter. 
 Some web browsers permit you to broadcast preference that you not be \xe2\x80\x9ctracked\xe2\x80\x9d online. At this time, eXtension does not modify your experience on the Site based upon whether such signal is broadcast. 
 Security 
 We are committed to protecting the personal information you submit to us, and we employ reasonable security measures to protect your personal information from being disclosed to individuals who are not described in this Privacy Policy. No method of transmission over the Internet, or method of electronic storage, is 100% secure, however. While we strive to use reasonable means to protect your personal information, we cannot guarantee its absolute security. 
 Children\xe2\x80\x99s Privacy 
 eXtension Foundation is committed to protecting the privacy of children. eXtension will never knowingly request personal information from anyone under the age of 13 without prior verifiable parental consent. 
 Contact information 
 If you have any questions regarding eXtension’s Privacy Policy, the practices of this Site, or your dealings with eXtension, please contact eXtension at privacy@extension.org 
 If eXtension needs, or is required, to contact you concerning any event that involves information about you, we may do so by email, telephone, or mail.

							 Professional Development 

						 
						 
							 The purpose of this page is to help in locating professional development offerings targeting Extension educators, administrators, and staff.\xc2\xa0 Such professional development takes many forms and formats, and is available from wide array of sources.\xc2\xa0 It is hoped that this page can serve as beginning point, or landing site to finding relevant professional development opportunities and resources.

							 Proposal Support Requests 

						 
						 
							 eXtension supports USDA and other agency grant projects. We have unique system for engaging Cooperative Extension professionals to design and strengthen local programs and interventions to solve local, state, regional, and national issues. We also have online tools available to support local solutions. 
 All faculty and staff from eXtension Foundation Member institutions can participate in our Impact Collaborative and use our Zoom webinar services. In addition, faculty from premium member institutions can participate in Innovation programs and teach online using our learning management system and its competency-based tracking and reporting (campus.extension.org). 
 eXtension user accounts and some tools are available to anyone with .gov, .mil and .edu email addresses for no fee regardless of membership in the eXtension Foundation: 
 
 question and answer application for groups focused on their specific topics, ask.extension.org 
 listing service for online events such as webinars, learn.extension.org 
 Publishing on articles.extension.org 
 
 These free eXtension tools and services are subject to change based on funding and priorities of the eXtension Foundation. 
 CHOOSE LETTER TO DOWNLOAD AND PRINT: 
 If you need letter of acknowledgment to use eXtension free tools listed above, click here 
 If you are principal investigator at basic member institution and need letter of acknowledgment including the free tools plus Zoom public webinars, click here 
 If you are principal investigator at premium member institution and need letter of acknowledgment including free tools, Zoom, and competency-based learning management system, click here 
 If you have budget for additional services, including member-only tools, Impact Collaboratives, competency framework development, and innovation support, contact us at ceoassist@extension.org 
 Published April 17, 2017

							 Results 

						 
						 
							 We empower Extension professionals with the proven process, mindset, and skillset to amplify their local impact. 
 Proven Process 
 The flagship program for eXtension is the Impact Collaborative. It started in 2015 as the Issue Corps program. The process includes design thinking, key informant expertise, evidence-based practice, and dynamic synergy. Results to date show we are: 
 
 Catalytic \xc2\xa083% were exposed to new or different ideas and/or viewpoints. 50% gained significant new ideas that moved their projects forward. 
 Engaging 82% interacted with other Extension professionals outside their normal professional circle. 
 Empowering 68% feel they can influence either their institution and/or their professional field in new ways after participating in the Impact Collaborative. 
 
 Extension professionals are working differently because of their Impact Collaborative participation. Join us on transformative journey from inspiration to impact, and discover what being more measurable, visible and innovative means to you. Several new cohorts are planned for 2018. 
 \xe2\x80\x9c really liked having the key informants \xe2\x80\x93 it gave us focused time to engage and get specific questions answered. \xe2\x80\x9d 
 See who has participated in the program: 2016 Food & Climate 2016-17 Communities of Practice 2017 Diversity & Inclusion 
 Mindset 
 eXtension sponsors fellowships and innovation projects to increase knowledge and explore pathways for Cooperative Extension professionals to innovate their programming. 
 Recent fellows have explored topics such as the Maker Movement Internet of Things citizen science networked knowledge data visualization and qualitative data analysis 
 Several fellows have worked with partner organizations. These include Global Open Data for Agriculture and Nutrition (GODAN), National Association of Extension Program and Staff Development Professionals (NAEPSDP), and Digital Green. These fellows are exploring methods to link research and Extension information in open, accessible ways, evaluation of Extension programming, and the applicability of successful Extension model used in Asia and Africa to U.S. programs. 
 Skillset 
 Through efforts such as the Horizon Report: Cooperative Extension Edition we are highlighting emerging trends, technologies, and tools. 
 eXtension hosts Zoom webinars for professionals from member institutions. eXtension also produces webinars in addition to hosting them. Of those produced by eXtension: 
 
 99% of participants indicated that they gained at least some information they could use right away 
 57% indicated they gained moderate amount or lot of information they could use right away 
 
 For more, visit professional development 
 Local Impact 
 Extension professionals are making difference in their local communities because of their connection with eXtension. Take look at some of the successes in these regions: 
 
 1890 Institutions 
 Northeast 
 Southern 
 North Central 
 Western 
 
 You can read more about their successes on the extension.org blog

							 Spark Lab Innovation Center 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
Spark Lab Innovation Center 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 Ohio State University 
 
 
 Location: 
Kenton, OH, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Mark Light 
 Role: Project Leader 
 
 
 \xc2\xa0Key Words 
 Maker Movement 
 4-H & Youth 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
This project will instill that inspiration or \xe2\x80\x9cspark\xe2\x80\x9d that youth and adults need to learn, discover, and grow in creative environment. This goes beyond just setting up \xe2\x80\x9cmakerspace\xe2\x80\x9d. It will be an overall center of innovation framed through the education lens of land grant university system. This project will transform local Extension office beyond the traditional into the innovative by bringing entrepreneurship, university education opportunities, and technology and maker space together in dynamic and still to be explored relationship. The project will connect local businesses, residents, and educators to promote innovation, learning, and creativity in hands-on space. It will also create physical space model that can be reproduced by Extension in other states nationwide. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 Spark Lab on the GO! 
 follow-up Innovation Grant (2017) will explore maker festivals in five states

							 Spatial Reasoning in Communication and Decision Making 

						 
						 
							 
 
 
 
 Project: 
Elevating of the Role of Spatial Reasoning in Communication and Decision Making in the Cooperative Extension System 
 
 
 
 
 Member Institution: 
 University of New Hampshire 
 
 
 Location: 
Durham, NH, USA 
 
 
 
 
 Key Experts: 
 
 
 
 
 Shane Bradt 
 Contact: Email 
 
 
 John McGee 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Summary: 
This project will empower CES staff to create interactive, online maps to collect and share spatial information, as well as, tell compelling stories. It will provide CES staff and administrators with access to relevant spatial data layers (i.e., census, political boundaries, watersheds, natural features) for their geographic region. It will advise Communities of Practice (CoP), and Learning Networks (LN) and members of the i-Three Issue Corps in the effective use of geospatial technologies in projects and grants. 
 
 
 
 
 Project Updates: 
 
 The\xc2\xa0 Map@Syst web site is now live! http://exgeospatial.org/ 
 Dr. Bradt received 2017 innovation grant to further develop the National Extension Web-mapping Tool (NEWT) 
 
 
 
 
 
 Recent Publications: 
 
 Mapping Your Way to Better Engagement

							 Terms of Use-Special Circumstances 

						 
						 
							 1. Conference Presentations 
 Papers that have been presented at eXtension or eXtension\xe2\x80\x93affiliated events are the intellectual property of the presenters/authors, even though they are published on the Site. 
 Permission to print or disseminate all or part of such papers is granted provided that the copies are not made or distributed for commercial advantage and that the title and authors of the paper appear on the printouts. To copy or disseminate otherwise, or to republish in any form, requires written permission from the authors. 
 2. Publications 
 
 Authors retain the copyright to their intellectual content, with eXtension owning the copyright to the presentation, whether as journal article, book, or monograph 
 Authors retain the right to publish their material elsewhere, and others may freely distribute it in electronic form, providing the original publication is acknowledged 
 eXtension has the right to edit the material to meet its standards 
 
 3. Electronic Discussion Forums 
 The Site may contain chat areas, forums, news groups, bulletin board Services and other facilities that permit you to communicate with other Users. Use of these Services is limited to post, send, and receive messages and materials appropriate to the Service. 
 eXtension does not regularly screen or monitor these Services; however, eXtension reserves the right to review information or materials posted and to remove any such information or materials if it violates the intention of the Service. eXtension reserves the right to block access to the Service by anyone who has routinely disregarded applicable terms of use guidelines and policies. 
 4. eXtension Campus 
 eXtension offers premium Users (\xe2\x80\x9cSubmitters\xe2\x80\x9d) the ability to submit fee-based Content (\xe2\x80\x9cCourse/Event\xe2\x80\x9d) to the eXtension Campus and designate fee for such Course/Event (\xe2\x80\x9cCourse/Event Fee\xe2\x80\x9d). To learn more about how to submit Course/Event to the eXtension Campus, please visit: https://www.extension.org/campus-procedures By submitting Course/Event to the eXtension Campus, Submitter warrants to eXtension that Submitter has the full right and authority to the Course/Event, and in all intellectual property rights in and to the Course/Event, to permit eXtension to offer the Course/Event to its Users of the Site. 
 eXtension will remove any Course/Event from eXtension Campus upon the written request of Submitter. eXtension will endeavor to remove the Course/Event within days of receipt of request to remove but in no event will that removal occur later than 10 days from receipt of the request. 
 eXtension will remit to Submitter on quarterly basis the Course/Event Fees collected by eXtension in the three months immediately preceding each quarterly payment date, net of any transaction fees and 5% retained by eXtension. Notification of any changes to payment of transaction fees or the portion retained by eXtension will be made not less than 90 days prior to implementation, and will take effect at the beginning of the calendar quarter next following that 90-day notice. 
 eXtension will provide to Submitter written report on or before each payment date detailing the course attendance, faculty member, gross Course/Event Fee collected, the transaction fees, the 5% retained by eXtension, and the net amount of the transfer. Reports and their associated payments will be made within 30 days following the end of each calendar quarter. 
 5. Paid Content and Subscription Services 
 In addition to the Content available for no charge through the Site, you may be offered the opportunity to purchase, subscribe to, or otherwise obtain access to premium Content (such as Course/Event), or other goods or services, through the Site for an additional fee. Unless otherwise indicated on the Site, purchases or subscriptions made by you through the Site cannot be exchanged and any fees or charges in connection with those purchases or subscriptions are non-refundable. Any purchase or subscription will be subject to any terms and conditions displayed in connection with the purchase or subscription in addition to the Terms of Use and by accessing or using any premium Content, you agree to be bound by the following additional terms and conditions: 
 You use the premium Content at your own risk and you are personally responsible for verifying its suitability to your needs. All information that you provide in connection with purchase or other transaction through the Site will be accurate complete and current. 
 Charges and Billing: You are responsible for providing valid bank account, mobile services account, or other payment method at the time of registration for an account. You represent and warrant that you are an authorized user of such payment method, and you agree to pay all charges resulting from your account at the prices then in effect, including any unauthorized charges incurred prior to notifying eXtension of such charges. You agree that eXtension may pass any payment information and related personally identifiable information to its designated service provider(s) for their use in charging you for your selection. If you have specified direct withdrawal from bank account as an applicable payment mechanism, you grant eXtension the right to debit the bank account associated with your account for all fees and charges incurred for such premium Content. You are responsible for payment of all costs associated with payment by wire transfer, or through third party invoicing or accounts payable service providers. All charges are exclusive of sales or other taxes and you are responsible for payment of any applicable state, local, and city taxes. eXtension reserves the right to modify or terminate membership plans, change prices, or institute new charges for any Content at any time with at least thirty (30) days\xe2\x80\x99 notice.

							 Frequently Asked Questions About eXtension Terms of Use 

						 
						 
							 This applies to the updated eXtension Terms of Use announced in June 2017. 
 Do have to accept the terms of use in order to create or publish content on any extension.org site? 
 Yes. In the past, people who did not accept the contributor agreement could still create and publish content. Replacing that agreement with this new terms of use also includes requirement to accept the terms in order to contribute to extension.org sites. Those not accepting the agreement will not be able to log into eXtension sites. 
 Does it matter if my institution is member of eXtension or not? 
 Several eXtension tools and services are available to anyone eligible for an eXtension ID regardless of the membership status of their institution. As such, everyone who has contributed, is currently contributing, or may contribute in the future, should be aware of the new terms of use. 
 What are 3rd party applications? 
 eXtension provides access to the following applications as part of the services offered to the Cooperative Extension System. Access via eXtension to some applications may be dependent on membership status of your institution. The following is list of links to the terms of use or terms of service for each of those applications. 
 
 Zoom:\xc2\xa0 https://zoom.us/terms 
 CourseMerchant (catalog.extension.org): http://www.coursemerchant.com/course-merchant-terms-conditions.php 
 Slack:\xc2\xa0 https://slack.com/terms-of-service 
 Basecamp:\xc2\xa0 https://basecamp.com/about/policies/terms 
 Google (access to Google using your eXtension address) https://support.google.com/accounts/answer/181692?hl=en 
 Google
 
 Terms of Service https://www.google.com/accounts/TOS 
 Google Privacy Policy https://www.google.com/intl/en/privacy.html 
 
 
 
 Do we need to contact past contributors and have them accept the new Terms of Use to keep their content active? 
 No. Anything edited or published prior to this change will not be affected. The requirement to accept the new Terms of Use only applies to content that is edited or published starting on the final “enforcement” date (currently set for June 20, 2017). 
 Who do contact for more information? 
 If you still have questions, contact Brenna Kotar ceoassistant@extension.org who will work with Chief Operating Officer Beverly Coberly to ensure your question is answered.

 Terms of Use-Special Circumstances 
			 
	 Related pages 



						 
							 Terms of Use-Special Circumstances 

						 
						 
							 1. Conference Presentations 
 Papers that have been presented at eXtension or eXtension\xe2\x80\x93affiliated events are the intellectual property of the presenters/authors, even though they are published on the Site. 
 Permission to print or disseminate all or part of such papers is granted provided that the copies are not made or distributed for commercial advantage and that the title and authors of the paper appear on the printouts. To copy or disseminate otherwise, or to republish in any form, requires written permission from the authors. 
 2. Publications 
 
 Authors retain the copyright to their intellectual content, with eXtension owning the copyright to the presentation, whether as journal article, book, or monograph 
 Authors retain the right to publish their material elsewhere, and others may freely distribute it in electronic form, providing the original publication is acknowledged 
 eXtension has the right to edit the material to meet its standards 
 
 3. Electronic Discussion Forums 
 The Site may contain chat areas, forums, news groups, bulletin board Services and other facilities that permit you to communicate with other Users. Use of these Services is limited to post, send, and receive messages and materials appropriate to the Service. 
 eXtension does not regularly screen or monitor these Services; however, eXtension reserves the right to review information or materials posted and to remove any such information or materials if it violates the intention of the Service. eXtension reserves the right to block access to the Service by anyone who has routinely disregarded applicable terms of use guidelines and policies. 
 4. eXtension Campus 
 eXtension offers premium Users (\xe2\x80\x9cSubmitters\xe2\x80\x9d) the ability to submit fee-based Content (\xe2\x80\x9cCourse/Event\xe2\x80\x9d) to the eXtension Campus and designate fee for such Course/Event (\xe2\x80\x9cCourse/Event Fee\xe2\x80\x9d). To learn more about how to submit Course/Event to the eXtension Campus, please visit: https://www.extension.org/campus-procedures By submitting Course/Event to the eXtension Campus, Submitter warrants to eXtension that Submitter has the full right and authority to the Course/Event, and in all intellectual property rights in and to the Course/Event, to permit eXtension to offer the Course/Event to its Users of the Site. 
 eXtension will remove any Course/Event from eXtension Campus upon the written request of Submitter. eXtension will endeavor to remove the Course/Event within days of receipt of request to remove but in no event will that removal occur later than 10 days from receipt of the request. 
 eXtension will remit to Submitter on quarterly basis the Course/Event Fees collected by eXtension in the three months immediately preceding each quarterly payment date, net of any transaction fees and 5% retained by eXtension. Notification of any changes to payment of transaction fees or the portion retained by eXtension will be made not less than 90 days prior to implementation, and will take effect at the beginning of the calendar quarter next following that 90-day notice. 
 eXtension will provide to Submitter written report on or before each payment date detailing the course attendance, faculty member, gross Course/Event Fee collected, the transaction fees, the 5% retained by eXtension, and the net amount of the transfer. Reports and their associated payments will be made within 30 days following the end of each calendar quarter. 
 5. Paid Content and Subscription Services 
 In addition to the Content available for no charge through the Site, you may be offered the opportunity to purchase, subscribe to, or otherwise obtain access to premium Content (such as Course/Event), or other goods or services, through the Site for an additional fee. Unless otherwise indicated on the Site, purchases or subscriptions made by you through the Site cannot be exchanged and any fees or charges in connection with those purchases or subscriptions are non-refundable. Any purchase or subscription will be subject to any terms and conditions displayed in connection with the purchase or subscription in addition to the Terms of Use and by accessing or using any premium Content, you agree to be bound by the following additional terms and conditions: 
 You use the premium Content at your own risk and you are personally responsible for verifying its suitability to your needs. All information that you provide in connection with purchase or other transaction through the Site will be accurate complete and current. 
 Charges and Billing: You are responsible for providing valid bank account, mobile services account, or other payment method at the time of registration for an account. You represent and warrant that you are an authorized user of such payment method, and you agree to pay all charges resulting from your account at the prices then in effect, including any unauthorized charges incurred prior to notifying eXtension of such charges. You agree that eXtension may pass any payment information and related personally identifiable information to its designated service provider(s) for their use in charging you for your selection. If you have specified direct withdrawal from bank account as an applicable payment mechanism, you grant eXtension the right to debit the bank account associated with your account for all fees and charges incurred for such premium Content. You are responsible for payment of all costs associated with payment by wire transfer, or through third party invoicing or accounts payable service providers. All charges are exclusive of sales or other taxes and you are responsible for payment of any applicable state, local, and city taxes. eXtension reserves the right to modify or terminate membership plans, change prices, or institute new charges for any Content at any time with at least thirty (30) days\xe2\x80\x99 notice.

							 National Delivery Infrastructure 

						 
						 
							 GO EXPLORING! 
 Explore the resources eXtension offers. 
 eXtension.org 
 The eXtension Foundation and its members share Cooperative Extension stories and resources at www.eXtension.org. Members access the tools and services for collaboration and creation.\xc2\xa0Go explore! 
 extension.org 
 Ask an Expert 
 See expert answers to questions submitted from the public. A\xc2\xa0person can submit\xc2\xa0a question to Ask an Expert and get an answer from an extension expert nationally. Sign in with your eXtension ID to update your profile and settings and to share your expertise by answering or reassigning questions. Become Ask an Expert savvy by reviewing our tutorials and instructions 
 ask.extension.org 
 Campus 
 variety of courses can be found on eXtension’s Campus that provide professional development topics for Cooperative Extension faculty and staff as well as their public audiences. Campus is available to individuals from premium member institutions as delivery tool of self-paced, certificate or even for-fee credit courses. Learn more about how to use Campus \xc2\xa0for your education delivery. 
 campus.extension.org 
 Catalog 
 Catalog serves as storefront or central listing of courses available through Campus http://campus.extension.org) \xc2\xa0as well as other courses, webinars, workshops, or ebooks that might be available throughout the Cooperative Extension System.\xc2\xa0 While it can easily point people to free online products that Extension might offer, Catalog accommodates specialized pricing options for fee-based events or resources. Learn more about how you can use Catalog 
 catalog.extension.org 
 Create 
 eXtension Resources are composed and published to eXtension using Create which is eXtension’s Drupal content management system. Community groups in eXtension use Create to collaborate and publish articles to eXtension. 
 create.extension.org 
 Learn 
 eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s professional development site is open to everyone! More and more of eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s learning opportunities are available to the public, and to Cooperative Extension faculty and staff. You\xe2\x80\x99ll find schedule of professional development and public webinars, recordings of previous eXtension webinars, and opportunities to interact with participants. Hosting webinar and promoting the event at Learn is easy and available to our members. Discover more about Learn with our Quick Reference Sheet .\xc2\xa0Explore! 
 learn.extension.org 
 People 
 eXtension’s account management system allows you to register with eXtension to access the internal side of all tools as well as find colleagues throughout the system and join community groups for the purposes of engaging with like minded individuals around topics that interest and support educational deliverables. In People, navigate to community group and Join the group to become more involved. If you don’t find group that matches your interests, start new group and promote to peers to begin new conversation. 
 people.extension.org 
 Search 
 Easy search access to resources provided by your Land-Grant institutions. Custom Google search of 1000+ Cooperative Extension Web sites. 
 search.extension.org 
 Slack 
 eXtension staff use\xc2\xa0 Slack for internal communications and chat. In addition we have extended this\xc2\xa0tool to our i-Three Issue Corp s\xc2\xa0members for use. 
 Zoom 
 eXtension staff use Zoom for video conferencing and webinars.

							 Delivering Online Courses 

						 
						 
							 
 The eXtension Foundation offers employees of its premium member institutions the free use of its online course system for the sale and delivery of courses to their clientele, including the incorporation of competency based curriculum if desired. This happens through package of two integrated sites, Campus (a Moodle 3.1+ platform) and Catalog store front facilitating free or fee-based access to courses on Campus.\xc2\xa0 Through incorporating competency frameworks in Campus and then linking course learning objects to elements of those frameworks, one is able to create competency based learning plans connecting learners to the courses and lessons that support those competencies.\xc2\xa0 While competency frameworks can be specified directly within Campus, eXtension also offers the use of framework builder provided by Eduworks Its Competencies and Skills System CASS allows the creation of frameworks in standardized format that is directly connected to Campus as well as other competency based platforms. 
 Where is it located? 
 The online course site is located at https://campus.extension.org while the catalog is at https://catalog.extension.org 
 How do get an account? 
 On Campus, using the “Create new account” link in the login block, user completes user profile which includes preferred user name, email address, password, and few other required items.\xc2\xa0 Upon submitting this profile, Moodle sends verification message to the email address entered.\xc2\xa0 The user accesses the link in the email message to verify the account, and then proceeds to enroll in courses of interest. 
 On Catalog, using the “Customer Login” link at the top of the page, user completes an online form, and is able to create an account without the step of the email verification.\xc2\xa0 Either of these methods creates accounts in the same database, so creating an account on Catalog allows the user to log in on Campus, and vice versa. 
 Why use it? 
 
 Anyone in the world can enroll 
 eXtension provides hosting and support 
 Makes courses available 24/7/365 
 Provides single site for all eXtension courses 
 Allows for multi-institutional collaboration in development 
 Provides incorporation of competency frameworks 
 Uses commercial storefront for sale of fee-based courses 
 
 Who can offer courses on it? 
 Anyone employed by an eXtension premium member institution and who has eXtension ID. 
 What features does it provide? 
 As Moodle 3.1 system, it provides full range of course delivery tools and services such as web pages, video, books, lessons, assignments, forums, chat, certificates, databases, glossaries, quizzes, journals, questionnaires, and competency frameworks. It also allows for sharing of resources and courses with other course developers and Moodle sites. 
 What if don’t have real “course,” but just few learning modules? 
 “Course” is the term used by Moodle to refer to container holding various learning objects.\xc2\xa0 Check out the blog post at https://www.extension.org/2016/01/27/when-is-a-course-not-a-course/ for more detail. 
 Other FAQs: 
 
 Can charge fees? Yes. Campus is tightly connected to catalog.extension.org which provides store front with built-in Paypal capability.\xc2\xa0 Details about that capability are located at https://www.extension.org/campus-procedures .\xc2\xa0 Other means of charging fees will require the use of an enrollment key issued to the user once payment is made. 
 Do have to pay to offer course on this site? \xc2\xa0 No, it is provided as service of eXtension to its premium member institutions. 
 Can control access to courses? \xc2\xa0 Moodle, the software running on Campus, provides different forms of access or enrollment control. The standard method is requiring an enrollment key (a password) when enrolling in the course. Issuing the enrollment key is reserved right of course teachers. Teachers can also impose limits in the duration one can be enrolled in course as well as time frames during which enrollment is open. 
 How does the site handle video? Video is generally managed in one of three different methods. It can be uploaded as file to the Moodle platform and delivered on demand to the user. teacher can provide link to video on third party site; e.g., YouTube, Vimeo. Or, video can be uploaded through Moodle to Kaltura platform eXtension provides and which streams the video on demand. 
 Can offer group activities? Moodle allows for the use of both groups and groupings (groups of groups) as means of controlling content delivery by group as well as exchange of information among participants; e.g., forums and chats among only members of specific group. 
 Can Moodle be used for instructor-led courses? Moodle provides several tools that facilitate instructor direct involvement in the learning activity. Forums, journals, chats and assignments are particularly designed for that purpose. Such engagement with the learners is particularly encouraged. 
 
 Where do get help with my questions or to get started using this system? 
 Send an email to campushelp@extension.org

							 Competency Based Education 

						 
						 
							 
 eXtension is implementing the capability for you to offer competency-based education (CBE) into your programs. CBE will also enhance eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s professional development offerings. With CBE, your programs will align more directly with the roles your programs support, such as volunteer training as well as increasing the skills of Extension professionals. For example, the Climate Learning Network CBE framework identifies the training and resources necessary to become Climate Literate Extension Professional. 
 Right now, we are developing tools to align resources and training with the needs of Extension Professionals. Our CBE vision is detailed in the two whitepapers below. The first whitepaper summarizes eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s goal of transforming professional development through competency-based education. The second whitepaper describes eXtension\xe2\x80\x99s Competency Framework Development (CFD) process which will be available in early 2017. 
 
 Whitepapers: 
 
 Competency Based Education [PDF] 
 CFD Whitepaper [PDF] 
 
 
 Pilot Competency Frameworks: 
 
 
 Working Out Loud Facilitator Competency Framework 
 Climate Literate Extension Professional Competency Framework 
 Urban County Extension Director Competency Framework 
 Impact Collaborative Member Framework

							 eXtension Catalog 

						 
						 
							 What is Catalog? 
 Catalog serves as storefront or central listing of courses available through Campus http://campus.extension.org) \xc2\xa0as well as other courses, webinars, workshops, or ebooks that might be available throughout the Cooperative Extension System.\xc2\xa0 While it can easily point people to free online products that Extension might offer, Catalog accommodates specialized pricing options for fee-based events or resources. For example, some features of Catalog include: 
 
 Bulk purchasing (buying multiple seats) in course with different levels of pricing; i.e., lower price per student once you get over certain number of seats purchased; 
 Bundled courses, where for one fee, student can gain access to more than one course; 
 Invoicing, in which Catalog generates an invoice to the student.\xc2\xa0 When the payment is received by the eXtension accounting office, Catalog administrator “releases” the student to begin accessing the course; 
 Discounted pricing through voucher codes that grant different levels of discount–in either percentage or dollar terms; 
 \xe2\x80\x9cBuy Now\xe2\x80\x9d buttons to facilitate payment of course fees from any other website where the buttons are displayed. 
 
 For users, Catalog and Campus share login credentials.\xc2\xa0 However, for the new user, Catalog simplifies the process of creating new login account by eliminating the need for email verification–one of the more frequent issues submitted to the Campus help desk. 
 Who can list educational offerings on it? 
 Anyone who has eXtension ID. 
 Other FAQs: 
 
 Where can get help? \xc2\xa0 eXtension staffs help desk to respond to any technical difficulties you may be having with this site.\xc2\xa0 Send an email to cataloghelp@extension.org 
 How do know if already have login name on Catalog? If you have enrolled in course at http://campus.extension.org \xc2\xa0 or logged in at that site within the past two years, you likely still have login account. Use the “Forgotten” link on the Catalog login page, and you can search for your credentials using either your user name or your email address. 
 am an Extension educator. How can get an educational event or course listed in this catalog?\xc2\xa0 Please review the information at http://create.extension.org/node/3180 The help desk staff will consult with you in deciding the most appropriate approach for listing your event or course. 
 Since Catalog can list webinars, will this replace Learn? \xc2\xa0 No, it is not practical to do so. Listings in Learn are created self serve by anyone with an eXtension ID.\xc2\xa0 Catalog is not self-serve.\xc2\xa0 Webinars included in Catalog are primarily for those instances where someone wishes to charge fees for access to webinar, or where they might want to package various resources, exams, certificates, badges, etc. to go along with the webinar. Catalog can also be used to broaden the publicity of the webinar. 
 What if my educational event or product is not on Campus? While Catalog facilitates seamless transfers to or from Campus, it also accommodates links to external websites and resources.\xc2\xa0 catalog listing could consist of nothing more than description with appropriate links to the external sites. 
 
 Where do get help with my questions or to get started using this system? 
 Send an email to cataloghelp@extension.org

 Summary: 
This project will prepare educator teams to focus on key messages and use innovative communication skills to plan communication strategy to help bring about behavior change. This project moves traditional face-to-face model to virtual learning experience especially designed to encourage teams to incorporate new and innovative technologies that meet their target audience\xe2\x80\x99s needs.
